headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: The Potential Perils of Speed Dating
abstract: As Morgan Stanley considers various partners to help it weather the storm, it is worth taking another look at last weekend’s hurried marriage on Wall Street.

headline: Does the Financial Crisis Threaten Your Job?
abstract: Alan B. Krueger, an economist at Princeton, explains how the credit crisis might affect Americans’ jobs.

headline: Former Refco Chief Barred from Executive Life
abstract: Phillip R. Bennett, the former chief executive of the failed commodities brokerage Refco, has agreed never to serve as an officer or director of a public company.

headline: Casting Call!
abstract: If you have data that is locked into some completely unplayable format, David Pogue wants to talk to you.

headline: Hot Times for Bankers in Gulf States
abstract: As banking opportunities remain fallow in the West, investment banks are continuing to send bankers to — and receive precious fees from — increasingly wealthy and spend-happy patrons in the Middle East.

headline: Owner Gives Executives Time to Fix Chrysler
abstract: Top Chrysler executives are determined to fix the ailing auto maker, and executives at Cerberus Capital Management, Chrysler’s new private-equity owner, say they will get the chance.

headline: Rick Wagoner, World-Record Holder
abstract: Over the last few days, General Motors has made two related announcements. First, the company disclosed that it had lost a stunning $15.5 billion in the second quarter. And then, G.M. followed up that bad news by letting it be known that the company’s board remained steadfast in its support for the chief executive Rick Wagoner. “Rick has the unified support of the entire board to a person,” the company’s lead outside director, George M.C. Fisher, told Bill Vlasic of The Times in an interview Wednesday morning. “We are absolutely convinced we have the right team under Rick Wagoner’s leadership to get us through these difficult times and to a brighter future.”

headline: Ackman Takes Pity on Lehman
abstract: William Ackman seems to be in an uncharacteristically mellow mood, at least when it comes to Lehman Brothers.

headline: Lipid Sciences to Review Options
abstract: Lipid Sciences said Tuesday that it has tapped Rodman & Renshaw to help the biotechnology company seek joint ventures, corporate partnerships or a potential sale.

headline: Emmys: Vote for ‘Memorable Moments’
abstract: Fans can watch clips and vote for their favorite moments online until Sept. 15.

headline: Patrick Reunites With Olbermann
abstract: “Dan Patrick is returning to television in September to work for NBC, beside his former ESPN partner Keith Olbermann, on the network’s ‘Football Night in America’ program.”

headline: Is Washington Mutual Running Out of Time?
abstract: As Wall Street scoured the financial industry Wednesday for the next weakest link after Lehman Brothers, it set its sights on a familiar target: Washington Mutual, the nation’s largest savings and loan.

headline: Bailout Forces Big Payouts in C.D.S. Market
abstract: The bailout of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac will post big consequences in yet another corner of the financial markets: contracts that protect $1.47 billion of the mortgage finance giants’ bonds against default.

headline: GLG Hires Two Morgan Stanley Traders to Replace Coffey
abstract: GLG Partners has brought in two senior traders from Morgan Stanley to replace Greg Coffey, the fund manager whose surprise resignation in April prompted $2 billion of redemptions.

headline: Vulture Investors Circle Over Weak Banks
abstract: Even before the ink dries on a proposed $700 billion bailout for the financial industry, Wall Street players have begun jockeying to be the first ones to snap up distressed investments on the cheap, according to The New York Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin and Eric Dash.

headline: A Sense That Wall St.’s Boom Times Are Over
abstract: The old Wall Street is giving way to a new one.

headline: CBS and Fox Duke It Out for Wednesday Night Ratings
abstract: While Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance” led Wednesday night’s ratings among adults 18 to 49, CBS finished first for the night in total viewers thanks to repeats of “Criminal Minds” and “CSI: NY.”

headline: NBC Says It Has Sold 85 Percent Of 2009 Super Bowl Commercials
abstract: NBC Universal, fresh off its record-setting Olympic coverage, has sold 85 percent of the commercial time available for the 2009 Super Bowl, with a dozen spots selling for $3 million each.

headline: Publicis to Buy Search Marketing Unit From Google
abstract: Publicis has decided to buy a search marketing services provider from U.S. search engine group Google as part of its push into digital advertising, the French advertising company said on Wednesday.

headline: Samsung Bid for SanDisk Would Shake Up Memory Market
abstract: Samsung said it may seek to buy SanDisk, which has a current market value of $3.2 billion. A deal would shake up the market for flash memory, which is used in many small electronic devices, from digital cameras to music players.

headline: October Surprise
abstract: The GDP report coming out a few days before the election could be a very bad one.

headline: Fortis Sells Stake in ABN Asset Management to Old Mutual
abstract: The Dutch bank Fortis said it had agreed to sell its 49 percent stake in a Chinese asset management business to a British asset management company, Old Mutual, for 165 million euros ($243 million).

headline: Google: We Did Not Erase Maps of Georgia
abstract: Google says it never had enough local data on Georgia to even offer a map.

headline: Steven Spielberg’s Director’s Cut
abstract: How did Hollywood lose Steven Spielberg?

headline: Olympics: ‘Aggregating a Huge Audience’
abstract: “We’re aggregating a huge audience for the Olympics,” NBC says.

headline: Goldman’s New Unit Said to Seek $50 Billion in Troubled Assets
abstract: Goldman Sachs, which last week announced that it would transform itself from an independent investment bank to a bank holding company, isn’t wasting any time trying find ways to profit from the move, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Music From the Past — Bringing Back the Epigonion
abstract: A group of researchers has recreated the music of an ancient harp-like instrument, the epigonion.

headline: Judge Lets Part of Rather’s CBS Lawsuit Proceed
abstract: A New York City judge says news anchor Dan Rather can proceed with his $70 million lawsuit accusing CBS of violating its contract with him when the network fired him.

headline: Would Romney Put Private Equity Back in the Glare?
abstract: Mitt W. Romney’s defeat in the Republican presidential primary earlier this year seemed to signal that private equity attacks would be left mostly out of the campaign. (The most direct recent critique was of Sen. John McCain’s fundraising ties to Henry R. Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.)

headline: No Government Help in a Lehman Bailout, Reports Say
abstract: Would-be suitors for Lehman Brothers have found a potential hurdle to acquiring the troubled investment bank: They likely won’t receive financial aid from the federal government.

headline: Lehman Leads Round for VideoIQ
abstract: VideoIQ, a video surveillance company, is set to announce a $10 million Series B funding round, CNet News reported.

headline: Private Equity Poses a Risk to Banks, SEIU Chief Says
abstract: Are private equity firms really the knights in shining armor they’re cracked up to be?

headline: Deal Chatter Surfaces as Sprint Plans to Raise Capital
abstract: Sprint Nextel, which on Wednesday reported a second-quarter loss of $344 million, said that it planned to raise $3 billion by selling three million shares of convertible preferred stock.

headline: Emmy Nominations: Younger Isn’t Always Better
abstract: “Only one actress nominated for an Emmy on Thursday is in her 20s.”

headline: Goldcorp Nets Gold Eagle for $1.5 Billion
abstract: Goldcorp has agreed to buy a rival Canadian gold mining company, Gold Eagle Mines, for about 1.5 billion Canadian dollars ($1.47 billion) to pick up the Bruce Channel gold discovery, an exploration project adjacent to Goldcorp’s flagship Red Lake operation.

headline: Credit Suisse’s Profits Fall, But Easily Beat Estimates
abstract: Credit Suisse posted a smaller-than-expected fall in second-quarter earnings on Thursday, sending its shares sharply higher in Zurich and giving some investors new hope that the turmoil in the financial sector was showing signs of easing.

headline: Iraq Veteran Sought for Soap Opera
abstract: An open casting call for ”All My Children” is far from business as usual: The soap opera is seeking an Iraq war veteran to play an injured veteran.

headline: Fortress Bestows $300 Million on Star Trader
abstract: A star trader at Fortress Investment Group has received a hefty $300 million share grant from the publicly-traded hedge fund and private equity firm, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Apple iTunes Store Is Blocked in China, Internet Users Say
abstract: Internet users in China have been complaining this week that they cannot access Apple’s iTunes Store. The start of the problems coincided with an announcement from a pro-Tibet group which said that around 40 Olympic athletes had downloaded a benefit album that was also carried on iTunes.

headline: Showtime Inks Seven-Year Deal With The Weinstein Co.
abstract: “CBS Corporation’s pay-TV subsidiary, Showtime Networks Inc., said Monday it has agreed to exclusively distribute movies made by The Weinstein Co. for seven years starting with films released theatrically in 2009,” the AP reports.

headline: G.M. Chief Dismisses Crisis Talk as Inaccurate
abstract: The chief executive of General Motors did his best to strike down rumors on Thursday that the automaker might seek bankruptcy protection soon.

headline: Spreading the Blame
abstract: Some members of Congress appear to want the bailout to pass, but also want to vote against it.

headline: Fannie Mae Investor Sues Underwriters
abstract: Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and three other banks have been hit with a shareholder lawsuit accusing the banks of failing to warn investors about proposed accounting-rule changes that lowered the value of preferred Fannie Mae stock.

headline: Barrick Bids for Cadence
abstract: Barrick Gold, the world’s largest gold producer, raised its bid for the oil and natural gas explorer Cadence Energy by 13 percent to widen its advantage over a competing bid.

headline: Microsoft Seeks an Ad Friend in Facebook
abstract: Microsoft has tried various tactics to expand its share of the lucrative online search business.

headline: Former Bear Chief to Leave JPMorgan
abstract: Updated: Alan Schwartz, the former chief executive of Bear Stearns, has decided not to stay at JPMorgan Chase, which bought Bear in March in an emergency deal that stunned Wall Street.

headline: Richemont to Spin Off Stake in Tobacco Company
abstract: The Swiss firm Richemont, maker of Cartier watches and Piaget jewelry, said it would spin off its stake in British American Tobacco under a revamp prompted by tax changes.

headline: IHS Buys Global Insight for $200 Million
abstract: Economic forecasting firm Global Insight announced Thursday that it had agreed to be purchased for $200 million by information giant IHS, continuing a wave of consolidation that has swept through the research industry.

headline: CBC and ABC Wedded to Teen Sitcom
abstract: The Hollywood Reporter: “ABC has teamed with Canadian Broadcasting Corp. on the new sitcom “18 to Life,” the first time that a U.S. and Canadian network have collaborated on a comedy in the pilot stage.” CBS and NBC have also collaborated with Canadian networks on series this year, but not in the pilot stage.

headline: Bloomberg Draws on Old Ties in Dealing With Crisis
abstract: As New York City’s banking industry descended into turmoil last weekend, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg picked up the telephone for a painful conversation with the president of Merrill Lynch, Gregory J. Fleming.

headline: Legg Mason’s Miller Says Buffett News Has Calmed Investors
abstract: Warren Buffett’s $5 billion investment in Goldman Sachs shows that shaken investors have been calmed by the $700 billion U.S. financial sector bailout plan and they are reopening their wallets to the industry, fund manager Bill Miller said, according to Reuters.

headline: Asia Stocks Take an Early Hit
abstract: Markets in Asia dropped in early trading on Thursday, as fears of a global credit crunch drove investors to dump stocks and park cash in safe havens like gold and Treasuries.

headline: Ratings: Another Evening News Low, This Time at ABC
abstract: “World News,” the evening newscast on ABC, received its lowest measured ratings in at least twenty years last week, according to Nielsen Media Research.

headline: Fresh Funds for MyToons
abstract: MyToons, a community and distribution platform for online animation, has raised an unspecified second round of funding from Syncom Venture Partners and past backer Barshop Ventures, paidContent.org reported. The amount of the new funding was not disclosed.

headline: Bill Miller’s Really Bad Bet
abstract: From Executive Suite: Bill Miller’s latest drubbing, at the hands of his big bet on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, has some in the investor community again wondering if the Legg Mason guru was smart or lucky in landing his 15-year winning streak, which has since dissolved into a bad series of fumbles.

headline: SpeedDate Hooks Up With V.C.s, Report Says
abstract: SpeedDate has raised $6 million in a second round of funding led by Menlo Ventures, TechCrunch reported.

headline: Banks Fail to Sell Some Clear Channel Debt
abstract: Underwriters led by Deutsche Bank are apparently still suffering a hangover from the $17.9 billion leveraged buyout of Clear Channel Communications.

headline: NBC Takes Monday Night, but Fox Wins in the Demo
abstract: “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” and “Prison Break” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Monday among adults 18 to 49, winning their respective time slots in that demographic despite struggling in total viewers. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the second season premiere of “Terminator” drew 6.3 million viewers at 8 p.m., while “Prison Break” garnered 6.5 million at 9 p.m.

headline: Prosecutors Seek to Delay Civil Case Against Bear Fund Managers
abstract: U.S. federal prosecutors asked securities regulators to delay a civil case against two former Bear Stearns hedge fund managers while they hold grand jury hearings in building a criminal case against the pair.

headline: Citigroup Puts Its Money Where Its Name Will Be
abstract: When Citigroup inked the agreement to make its name synonymous with New York baseball in November 2006, the banking giant had just ended its third quarter with net income of $5.3 billion. And the the 20-year, $400 million deal to name the Mets’ new ballpark Citi Field garnered no small amount of attention, given that it was the most expensive stadium rights deal in the United States at the time.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Starting Businesses as an Encore for Women
abstract: Exploring entrepreneurship as an option for women in later life.

headline: GT Solar Shares Swoon After I.P.O.
abstract: GT Solar hasn’t been burning very bright since its initial public offering, which raised $500 million on Wednesday.

headline: When Money Can’t Get Past the Velvet Rope
abstract: For high-rolling investment bankers and hedge funders, finance bestows great sums of money — but not the cachet needed to get into top London or New York nightlife hot spots.

headline: Home Sale Blues
abstract: Sold any new houses lately?

headline: State of Florida Sues Countrywide
abstract: Florida sued Countrywide Financial and its chief executive, Angelo R. Mozilo, on Monday, accusing it of engaging in unfair and deceptive trade practices in mortgage lending, Reuters reported.

headline: Icahn Raises Stake in Biogen Idec
abstract: Carl C. Icahn reported on Monday that he owns a 6.03 percent stake in the common stock of biotechnology company Biogen Idec, which the activist investor has been pressuring to put itself for up sale.

headline: Introducing Alan Krueger
abstract: Welcoming Alan B. Krueger, an economist at Princeton, to our panel of Daily Economists.

headline: A.I.G. Pays Its Ex-Chief $47 Million
abstract: The American International Group said it paid a $47 million severance package to its former chief executive, Martin J. Sullivan, whose resignation took effect on Tuesday.

headline: Americans Are Watching More TV Than Ever, Nielsen Reports
abstract: Somehow, despite more distractions than ever, we’re finding even more time to plant ourselves in front of screens.

headline: ArcelorMittal to Buy Iron-Ore Unit in $810 Million Deal
abstract: ArcelorMittal will buy London Mining’s Brazilian iron-ore unit for about $810 million, which includes a payment to take on loans of about $46 million.

headline: Buffett Makes His Move as Bailout Debate Rages
abstract: Warren E. Buffett, the country’s most famous investor and one of the world’s richest men, announced on Tuesday that he would invest $5 billion in Goldman Sachs, the embattled Wall Street titan, in a move The New York Times’s Ben White says could bolster confidence in the financial markets.

headline: Metalloinvest Readies I.P.O.
abstract: Metalloinvest has appointed Merrill Lynch, Credit Suisse and Deutsche global to coordinate an upcoming initial public offering, Reuters said citing a report in the Kommersant business daily.

headline: Investors Circle Xeround
abstract: Software developer Xeround has closed its second round of financing with an additional $16 million, The Seattle Times reported.

headline: New Offshore Bank Limits for U.S. Clients, UBS Says
abstract: Faced with a federal investigation into its private banking practices, the Swiss banking giant UBS said on Thursday that it would stop offering offshore banking services to clients in the United States.

headline: Fidelity Shows Its Hand on Goldman, Citi, JPMorgan
abstract: Which financial firms are primed to fare well as the markets continue to tremble? According to Fidelity Investments‘ flagship Magellan fund, they’re Goldman Sachs and the American International Group.

headline: With Soccer Deal, Abu Dhabi Seeks to Score Against Dubai
abstract: Sports teams have long been the playthings of rich men, but by swooping in to buy the English soccer club Manchester City, Abu Dhabi’s ruling family has demonstrated just how much money it now takes to play in the big leagues.

headline: Andor Capital to Close Down
abstract: Hedge fund Andor Capital Management is to shut down and return money to investors, The Financial Times reported.

headline: A Prescient Literary Metaphor
abstract: A tale of Scarlett O’Hara, Congress and the markets.

headline: Fed Sets Rules Meant to Stop Deceptive Lending Practices
abstract: The Federal Reserve adopted sweeping rules on Monday aimed at barring abusive or deceptive mortgage lending practices of the kind that analysts say have led to widespread delinquencies and foreclosures, a collapse of the housing market and an economic downturn.

headline: Laurence Fishburne Is Prime ‘CSI’ Suspect
abstract: Laurence Fishburne is in talks to replace William Petersen on “CSI.”

headline: Sprint and SK Telecom Said to Discuss Partnership
abstract: Sprint Nextel, the wireless carrier, is in early talks to form a partnership with SK Telecom of South Korea to share information about mobile phones and other technology, according to people briefed on the talks.

headline: Nation’s Financial Industry Gripped by Fear
abstract: Fear and greed are the stuff that Wall Street is made of. But, as The New York Times’s Ben White and Jenny Anderson report, inside the great banking houses, those high temples of capitalism, fear came to the fore this weekend.

headline: Fed Seeks At Least $70 Billion to Help A.I.G.
abstract: Updated: The Federal Reserve has asked JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs to help gather $70 billion to $75 billion in loans to help prop up the American International Group, the giant insurance company, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Friday’s Links: Networking Lessons from Ben Franklin
abstract: Inspired by Benjamin Franklin’s Junto, two friends started the Silicon Valley Junto as a way to exchange ideas and network with their peers.

headline: Tech I.P.O. Slump May Continue
abstract: Tech companies once dominated the U.S. calendar for initial public offerings — but not anymore.

headline: When Buyout Funds Seek Greener Pastures
abstract: Can private equity find its fortunes abroad?

headline: Napster Gets a Lift From Proxy Advisory Firms
abstract: Napster, the one-time leader in digital music downloads, received support on Monday from two proxy advisory firms as it seeks to stave off an attack by three dissident shareholders, according to The Los Angeles Times’s Technology blog.

headline: UBS Aims For Speedy Settlement With U.S. Regulators
abstract: UBS, under scrutiny in the United States for the conduct of its offshore private-banking unit for wealthy Americans, hopes to reach a settlement with the Justice Department and regulators within the next two weeks, The Financial Times reported.

headline: The Bailout’s Collapse: A Bank Lobbyist’s View
abstract: From Leslie Wayne, a DealBook colleague:

headline: Bits Upgrade Means No Commenting Until Mid-Afternoon
abstract: The Bits blog is going through a software upgrade. No new posts or reader comments will be published until mid-afternoon, when we expect the upgrade to be complete.

headline: Merrill Names New Head of Canadian Equity Research
abstract: Merrill Lynch has named telecommunications analyst Glen Campbell the head of Canadian equity research. Mr. Campbell has been with Merrill Lynch since 1996 and replaces Ihor Danyliuk, who is leaving the firm, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Thomson Reuters Reports Lower Profit on Costs of a Merger
abstract: Thomson Reuters said on Tuesday that second-quarter earnings fell 54 percent as costs to buy and integrate Reuters cut into profit.

headline: Live qualifying blogging
abstract: I’ve done this once or twice before, and figure that since we’re at Spa and could possibly have a lively qualifying session, that I would do some live commentating again. Hoping that it will be wild….

headline: Morgan Stanley to Pay $1.5 Million in Auction-Rate Settlement
abstract: Massachusetts officials said on Thursday that Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay $1.5 million to reimburse investments in auction-rate securities by the cities of New Bedford and Hopkinton.

headline: Batteries Near Dead, Transmeta Is Up for Sale
abstract: Fallen chip superstar Transmeta is looking for a buyer, leaving behind an industry now obsessed with saving power.

headline: Lyons and Mankiewicz Replace Ebert and Roeper
abstract: One day after Roger Ebert and Richard Roeper said they were departing their syndicated movie review show, Disney Domestic Television announced two new hosts.

headline: $20 Billion Worth of Asian I.P.O.’s Shelved in First Half
abstract: Asian I.P.O.s worth about $20 billion have been shelved this year due to turmoil in the market and bankers are beginning to fear a rush in the second half should conditions improve, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Walden Eyeing $500 Million Fund for Asian Investments
abstract: Walden International plans to launch a global fund early next year to raise up to $500 million as it steps up investment in China and India, Reuters reported citing a top official.

headline: The Country’s Dominant Reality TV Show: The Economy
abstract: The threat to people’s pocketbooks has supplanted politics as the country’s dominant reality TV show.

headline: Fair Value Follies
abstract: As banks and politicians press to be allowed to stop using market values in their financial statements, the SEC and the Financial Accounting Standards Board are about to issue some sort of statement.

headline: McCormick Sells Unit to Win Deal Approval
abstract: McCormick & Company, a leading seasonings retailer, has agreed to sell Season-All line as part of a deal to gain antitrust approval for its $605 million deal to buy Lawry’s Seasoned Salt from Unilever.

headline: XTO Energy Reaches $2.1 Billion in Gas Deals
abstract: XTO Energy said it is buying gas properties across several states from various unnamed parties for $2.1 billion.

headline: 2 More Prison Terms in National Century Fraud
abstract: Two more defendants were sentenced to prison Thursday in a $1.9 billion corporate fraud case.

headline: UBS Executives Knew of Possible Breaches in 2006
abstract: Senior executives at Swiss bank UBS knew some of their bankers had acted in a way that meant they risked breaching American securities laws at least a year before the U.S. inquiries began, The Financial Times reported, citing a letter.

headline: In Volatile Times, Investors Tune in All and Any Predictions
abstract: The news hit Wall Street trading floors on the morning of July 2: Some analyst at Merrill Lynch was saying the General Motors Corporation might go bankrupt.

headline: Banks Borrow Record Sums from Fed
abstract: Banks borrowed a record amount of funds from the Federal Reserve in the latest week as the year-old credit crisis took a persistent toll, while the commercial paper market continued to contract, signaling tough conditions for short term borrowers.

headline: Banks Lost Fight to Halt Bets Against Financial Firms
abstract: Many momentous events transpired this weekend: the likely collapse of Lehman Brothers, the impending purchase of Merrill Lynch by Bank of America and the apparent failure of American International Group to raise enough money to stave off a credit rating upgrade.

headline: Royal Bank of Canada Mulled Lehman Bid, Report Says
abstract: Royal Bank of Canada considered buying Lehman Brothers in July, but decided against the move because it doubted the bank’s ability to shore up its balance sheet, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Unilever Sells North American Detergents Unit for $1.45 Billion
abstract: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer goods giant, said Monday that it will sell its North American laundry unit, including brands like All, Wisk and Snuggle, to Vestar Capital Partners for about $1.45 billion.

headline: Report on Fannie, Freddie Said to Spark Sell-Off
abstract: Stocks fell sharply on an otherwise quiet Monday as jitters about the mortgage industry prevailed in low-volume trading, sending shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to 17-year lows.

headline: Conventions: Short-Changed by the Networks?
abstract: We’ve only seen one night of the Democratic convention, but already critics are chastising the broadcast networks for only covering one hour of the proceedings each evening.

headline: Virtual Worlds Bring in Real Venture Dollars
abstract: Virtual experiences are becoming a thing of serious reality when it comes to raising venture capital these days. Citing data from Virtual Worlds Management, BusinessWeek reported that startups selling virtual goods and offering virtual experiences have raised $345 million in the first half of 2008.

headline: Mahindra Is Not Courting Hummer, Executive Says
abstract: Mahindra & Mahindra is “not pursuing” the acquisition of General Motors’ Hummer brand, Anand Mahindra, the Indian car company’s managing director, told reporters Monday.

headline: Emmys: ‘Mad Men’ Set to Make History
abstract: “Mad Men” is expected to make Emmy history when U.S. television’s highest honors are handed out on Sunday.

headline: New LG Blu-ray Player Streams Netflix — With Drawbacks
abstract: A new Blu-ray player from LG will be able to stream movies from Netflix, but technical limitations mean the video quality of Netflix films will be standard-definition — at best.

headline: Anticipation in Valencia
abstract: The feeling in Valencia is that while we’re endlessly comparing this place to Monaco, we’re mostly doing it in terms of defining the differences, not the similarities. Everything we have seen so far this weekend suggests that we will certainly NOT be in for a Monaco – like procession. I think most people – both within and outside the teams – expect the race tomorrow to present some big surprises.

headline: Japanese Financial Stocks Tumble in Early Trading
abstract: The Nikkei average slid 2.7 percent to hit a one-month low on Tuesday as exporters such as Canon and bank shares were battered after jitters about the health of the financial system in the United States re-emerged.

headline: Retail Bankruptcies to Grow, Restructuring Pro Says
abstract: This year has proven tough for a slew of retailers, as the credit crunch and the slowdown in consumer spending forced an increasing number of chains into bankruptcy.

headline: Monday Ratings: ‘Dancing’ Remains Strong
abstract: Week two of “Dancing With the Stars” remained strong in the ratings on Monday as 19.3 million viewers tuned in to ABC from 8 to 10 p.m.

headline: An Unusual Political Player: ‘The View’
abstract: “The View” interview of John McCain ranked as the fourth-most-watched in the show’s 12-year history.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Bloomberg L.P. Braces for Wall Street Fallout
abstract: Another victim of the Wall Street collapse may be the maker of those ubiquitous data terminals on every financial firm’s floor.

headline: Inside the Center of the Storm
abstract: DealBook presents an exclusive look at the scene inside Lehman Brothers, after the investment bank filed for one of the largest bankruptcies in corporate history.

headline: Stealthy iList Raises $1.5 Million, Report Says
abstract: IList, a start-up in stealth mode, has raised $1.5 million from Draper Fisher Jurvetson, Dmitry Shapiro, the founder of Veoh, and Alex Bard the founder of Goowy, TechCrunch reported.

headline: William Petersen Leaving ‘CSI’
abstract: William Petersen is leaving ”CSI: Crime Scene Investigation.”

headline: How a Chain of Mistakes Hurt Shares of United
abstract: The swift, sharp and short-lived collapse of United Airlines shares last Monday was followed by a week of finger-pointing, The New York Times’s Miguel Helft reports.

headline: Overhaul of Financial Rules Expected to Pick Up Pace
abstract: Efforts to overhaul U.S. financial regulation are expected to gather pace next year, as a new Congress and administration seek to safeguard public money put at risk by recent rescue measures, according to Reuters.

headline: A.I.G.: So Many Questions
abstract: The bailout of American International Group already seems like years ago, but the $85 billion loan transaction raises a host of legal issues for both bank finance and M&A lawyers. It also raises a number of questions for which we have no answers yet. Here are a few of my thoughts on all of it.

headline: Icahn’s Hedge Funds Said to Stumble
abstract: Carl C. Icahn has hit a bump along the hedge-fund road.

headline: A Partnership Solution for Investment Banks?
abstract: The travails of Lehman Brothers and the demise of Bear Stearns have me thinking — would these Wall Street firms have ended up in their respective messes if investment banks had never been permitted to go public?

headline: Prince Lands New Job as Consultant
abstract: Charles O. Prince III, the former chairman and chief of Citigroup, has found a new home, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Meet The Chiefs
abstract: As part of its rescue plan for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government has dismissed to the current chief executives of the mortgage giants and replaced them with two veterans of the financial world.

headline: Has Oil Been Good for Iraq?
abstract: Two Iraqi reporters launch into a heated late-night discussion about whether oil has actually been good or bad for Iraq throughout its recent history.

headline: Wall Street Research Hits A New Low
abstract: From Executive Suite: With all of the problems Wall Street research has suffered in recent years, word of Lehman Brothers’s plagiarism scandal is probably the most laughable yet. And it only highlights the already sorry state of the industry.

headline: Thain’s Change: From Assurance to Desperation
abstract: From cockiness to capitulation. From distinction to desperation. From pride to panic.

headline: The End is Nigh (And That is Good)
abstract: A report out today from Alex Patelis, an economist at Merrill Lynch, discusses the world economy.

headline: CBS Wants More Time To Advertise Its New Advertising Show
abstract: CBS is pushing back the premiere of a reality show about advertising to give the network more time to advertise.

headline: Amazon Enters the File-Shipping Business
abstract: Amazon’s computing services push has taken a new turn with a MP3, photo and software delivery business.

headline: Bell Canada Reaches New Buyout Agreement
abstract: Bell Canada announced it has renegotiated its deal to sell itself to a consortium of investors for about $50 billion, marking the end of months-long saga over the fate of the largest buyout in history.

headline: S.E.C. Inquiry Said to Target Lehman Rumors
abstract: Dozens of hedge funds have received subpoenas from the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of its investigation into rumors circulating about Lehman Brothers in recent weeks, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: A Wikipedian Challenge: Convincing Arabic Speakers to Write in Arabic
abstract: A nagging undercurrent to the Wikimania conference in Alexandria, Egypt, is the paucity of articles on the Arabic-language version of Wikipedia. Many Arabic speakers prefer to contribute to English Wikipedia instead of the version in their own language.

headline: Apple Imposes Gag Rule on iPhone Application Makers
abstract: It’s no secret that lots of companies are going to release applications for the iPhone. But Apple is nonetheless banning them from discussing their plans until noon Thursday.

headline: Cisco Invests in Russian Fund
abstract: Cisco has made an anchor investment in Almaz Capital Russia Fund I, a fund that will focus on Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States, the company said in a press release.

headline: From Journalist to Novelist
abstract: Linda Villarosa writes a guest post on the challenge of moving from journalist to novelist.

headline: Change Capital Fund Bought by a Consortium
abstract: Change Capital Fund, a 300 million euro ($423.3 million) retail buyout fund managed by Change Capital Partners, has changed hands, The Deal.com reported.

headline: European Shares Take a Hit As Crises Deepens
abstract: European shares fell heavily on Monday as fallout from the credit crisis hit the region’s banking sector, forcing partial nationalization of two banks and leaving investors to ponder the impact of a U.S. bailout plan.

headline: Judge Rejects Countrywide Settlement
abstract: A federal bankruptcy judge has rejected a settlement involving Countrywide Financial, the mortgage lender, saying he was not convinced that it was fair to nearly 300 borrowers who claimed to have been hurt by the company’s abusive practices.

headline: Banks Said to Vie for Deutsche Bahn I.P.O.
abstract: Fierce competition is apparently afoot for the remaining contracts for the initial public offering of German rail operator Deutsche Bahn.

headline: Quiz Time! Today’s Problem: Chasing Daylight
abstract: From the desk of David Pogue’s son: Can a plane fly around the equator so fast that it never saw the sun set?

headline: Drought of Stock Offerings Gets Deeper
abstract: The drought of U.S. initial public offerings became even more severe in the third quarter, according to preliminary league-table data from Thomson Reuters.

headline: Former AOL Chief in the Spotlight Again
abstract: As Yahoo‘s shareholders gathered Friday for what is likely to be a contentious annual meeting, the Los Angeles Times has a profile of Jonathan Miller, the former AOL chief, now at Velocity Interactive Group, who may get a seat on Yahoo’s board.

headline: Suez, GdF Merger Approved
abstract: After two and a half years of delays, a 91 billion euro ($144 billion) merger of Suez and Gaz de France was approved by shareholders on Wednesday, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: Investor Chief Plans Buying Spree
abstract: While announcing first-half results, Investor chief executive Börje Ekholm said the company is planning to start acquiring companies within the next six to 18 months, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Amid Olympics, NBC’s Competitors Post Record Low Ratings
abstract: “From the ratings week ending Aug. 17, ABC, CBS and Fox each had their lowest-rated and least-watched week in recorded People Meter history.”

headline: I’m Not That Heartthrob
abstract: Being stared at while working in foreign countries is nothing new to me. I am a tall white guy walking around Iraq with two massive cameras.

headline: Multi-Network Cancer Telethon Donations Top $100 Million
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Callan Leaves Lehman for Credit Suisse
abstract: Erin Callan, whose rise and fall at Lehman Brothers transfixed Wall Street, has resigned to join Credit Suisse.

headline: Citadel Jumps into Huntsman-Hexion Fray
abstract: A month after D.E. Shaw & Company tried to help broker a resolution over the merger between Huntsman and Hexion Specialty Chemicals, offering to provide financing to help smooth the way, rival hedge fund Citadel Investment Group has followed suit.

headline: After Delay, KKR Finds a Way to Go Public
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the storied private equity firm, is again preparing to become a public company on the New York Stock Exchange, the firm said Sunday.

headline: Citi Analysts Play Matchmaker For Yahoo
abstract: Nearly two months have passed since Microsoft pulled the plug on its bid for Yahoo. It now looks as if the deal has little hope of being resurrected, even with Carl Icahn threatening to oust Yahoo’s board.

headline: Olympics: Nearly 30 Million Viewers on Monday
abstract: The four-night Beijing Olympics average of 30.4 million is 5.7 million better than the Athens figure for the same period in 2004.

headline: Shares of Exchanges Sink With Markets
abstract: The bear market in stocks has turned into a bear market for the world’s stock exchanges.

headline: Bristol-Myers Boosts Imclone Bid
abstract: The drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb said on Monday that it had raised its offer for Imclone Systems to $62 a share from $60, in an effort to seal a deal for the part of the biotechnology that it doesn’t already own.

headline: SailPoint Raises $6.5 Million in Third Round
abstract: SailPoint Technologies, a maker of identity management software, has raised $6.5 million in a third round of funding.

headline: Walgreen Begins $1.3 Billion Debt Offering
abstract: Walgreen started its first public debt offering in over two decades on Tuesday, The Chicago Tribune reported. The move was intended to establish long-term funding for some recent acquisitions.

headline: Georgia Takes a Beating in the Cyberwar With Russia
abstract: In addition to the bloody shooting war between Georgia and Russia, there is a quieter battle going on in cyberspace.

headline: Wall Street Posts Worst Loss Since 2001
abstract: In another unnerving day for Wall Street, investors suffered their worst losses since the terrorist attacks of 2001, and government officials raced to prevent the financial crisis from spreading, writes the New York Times’s Stephen Labaton.

headline: Free the Phone, and Venture Capital Will Follow
abstract: The trend toward allowing consumers to use a wider variety of applications on their cellphones is leading to greater investment in such applications, according to a research firm.

headline: Day and Night
abstract: Here in Iraq you must finish what you want to do before the sun sets.

headline: TPG Said to Close on $30 Billion Fund
abstract: As rivals seem to be struggling to meet their fundraising targets, TPG has quietly raised a fresh $30 billion war chest to target deals across a broad range of spectrum, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Is It Time To Break Up Google?
abstract: Just kidding!

headline: What Is Greenberg Weighing for A.I.G.?
abstract: Is Maurice R. Greenberg considering a bid for his former employer in an effort to save it?

headline: SlotMusic’s Obituary Gets Written Quickly
abstract: People who write off SanDisk’s effort to create a format to sell music on tiny flash memory cards ignore who actually defines what technology survives.

headline: Coke Bids for Chinese Juice Giant
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said Wednesday that it had made a bid to acquire one of China’s largest juice makers for about $2.5 billion.

headline: Convio Pulls the Plug on I.P.O.
abstract: Convio, a software and service operator for non-profit organizations, said Monday that it was withdrawing its plans for an initial public offering, nearly a year after it filed to raise about $86 million in an I.P.O.

headline: SAG Determined to Seek Better Deal
abstract: “A day after losing a bid to scuttle a rival union’s new labor contract with Hollywood’s studios, Screen Actors Guild leaders insisted on Wednesday they were determined to negotiate a better deal, despite the studios’ assertion that bargaining is over.”

headline: Tesco Pays $1.9 Billion for R.B.S.’ Stake in Joint Venture
abstract: Tesco on Monday inked a 950 million pound ($1.9 billion) deal to buy Royal Bank of Scotland Group‘s 50 percent stake in their joint venture, Tesco Personal Finance, as the British supermarket chain moves agressively into the British banking market.

headline: Google’s Tracking of Users Can Also Increase Privacy Protection
abstract: We’ve written a lot about the privacy concerns raised by Google and other companies tracking users’ activities on the Web, but the tracking has upsides, too.

headline: S.E.C. Extends Short-Sale Limits
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission extended on Tuesday an emergency limit on short sales in shares of Freddie Mac, Fannie Mae and 17 brokerage firms as it prepares broader rules to thwart stock manipulation.

headline: Sun Microsystems Has a Fan in Memphis
abstract: From Bits: Despite the troubles plaguing Sun Microsystems, O. Mason Hawkins of Southeastern Asset Management apparently likes what he sees, having invested a cool $1 billion in the company, mainly since March.

headline: Fluidigm Pulls I.P.O.
abstract: Fluidigm, a biotech company financed in part by Lehman Brothers‘ health-care venture capital arm, has pulled its initial public offering amid chaos in the financial markets.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.
