abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: South Korea Court Convicts Ex-Samsung Boss
abstract: A South Korean court convicted former Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-hee on Wednesday for evading taxes and fined him 110 billion won ($109 million), but said his crimes did not justify a prison term.

headline: Dizzywood Raises $1 Million in Fresh Cash
abstract: Dizzywood, a virtual world start-up catering to kids, has raised $1 million from the European Founders Fund, peHUB reported, citing a regulatory filing.

headline: Ratings for Leno and Letterman Dip
abstract: Bill Carter reports on a ratings shift in late-night:

headline: China Qinfa Plans I.P.O.
abstract: China Qinfa Group plans to raise $100 to $150 million from a Hong Kong initial public offering in the next two months, a source close to the deal told Reuters

headline: A Facebook for Sports Fans
abstract: David Katz believes that his Web site, sportsfanlive.com, will compete well against established sports sites he views as stodgy and too congested for fans to wade through.

headline: The I.B.M. Deal Machine: A Seller’s View
abstract: From our colleagues at Bits:

headline: Two cases of F1 justice done
abstract: Fernando Alonso on Saturday threw a fit after his car broke down in qualifying. After setting the fastest time in practice he had good reason to think he would be able to do well in qualifying, then the car broke down. I’d never seen him so demonstratively angry. On race day, it all came together and Alonso showed why he is so good, taking advantage of everything, he and his Renault team pulled off a nearly impossible to imagine victory. It was justice of a kind.

headline: Obama Bets $5 Million on Olympic Viewers
abstract: Via sib-blog The Caucus: Senator Barack Obama’s campaign will spend $5 million on advertisements during NBC’s coverage of the Summer Olympic Games next month, an NBC spokeswoman confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: Never Mind
abstract: The general expectation, which I shared, was that the GDP number today would make people think the economy was doing fine, and the jobs number tomorrow would convey the opposite impression.

headline: Game Over: Scrabulous Shut Down on Facebook
abstract: The developers of Scrabulous have blocked U.S. and Canadian users from playing the popular Facebook game a week after Hasbro sued to block the copycat of its Scrabble word game.

headline: Cohen Backs Buyout of Former ABN Amro Fund
abstract: Sir Ronald Cohen, co-founder of Apax Partners, is backing the management buyout of ABN Amro‘s former hedge fund arm a mere two and a half years after the Dutch bank bought the business, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Bank of America May Assume All Countrywide Debt, Analyst Says
abstract: Bank of America is primed to assume all debt of the former Countrywide Financial, independent research firm CreditSights said, a move that would alleviate worries of Countrywide bondholders.

headline: Tropicana to Auction Casino
abstract: Tropicana Entertainment has decided to put one of its riverboat casinos up for sale, after a deal for Casino Aztar has been hanging in limbo for some months.

headline: Olympics: Early Ratings For Opening Ceremonies
abstract: “The 21.5 overnight rating was the best on record for a non-domestic Summer Games opener, with the closest being an 18.5 from Sydney in 2000.”

headline: Britney Spears to Raise Curtain on MTV Awards
abstract: Britney Spears is to star at this year’s MTV Video Music Awards.

headline: Paddock poker (Part II)
abstract: Later yesterday evening after posting my little story below about paddock poker, I took a shuttle bus back to the parking lot from the paddock and in the bus I heard a British journalist talking about the paddock poker too, so I began talking to him and his colleague about it. He then had this very funny story to relate, although I have no way to confirm whether it is true or not. It is fun, and it seems to fit the characters well:

headline: A Strong Comeback for Banking Stocks
abstract: Battered financial shares roared back Wednesday in their biggest one-day rally ever, as euphoria tinged with a bit of panic swept Wall Street.

headline: New Year May Bring Retailer Bankruptcies
abstract: For many of the nation’s retailers, this is shaping up to be the most critical holiday season since the recession of the early 1980s. Chains that fare poorly could end up as ghosts of Christmases past, The New York Times’s Stephanie Rosenbloom reported.

headline: Lehman’s Asset Sale Won’t Fly, Analyst Says
abstract: News that Lehman Brothers has invited offers for its highly prized asset management unit, which includes Neuberger Berman, is the talk of Wall Street.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Starts an iPhone Blog
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers, the venture capital firm that is investing its $100 million iFund in applications for the iPhone and iPod touch, has a new blog that will discuss trends in mobile.

headline: EBay in Talks to Buy Stake in Korea’s Gmarket
abstract: EBay is set to gobble up a large chunk of the Korean auction site and Internet retailer Gmarket.

headline: Huntsman Scores Some Points
abstract: Some of you might have noticed Thursday’s spike of about $1 or so in shares of Huntsman, the chemical company in a legal face-off with Hexion Specialty Chemicals over their troubled merger deal.

headline: AIG Falls as Analyst Predicts More Pain
abstract: American International Group’s stock took a beating Monday morning after Credit Suisse analyst Thomas Gallagher slashed his earnings forecast for the insurance behemoth.

headline: Legal Fees Set in Enron Case
abstract: Lawyers for investors in Enron will get $688 million in fees for recovering more than $7.2 billion from its lenders, auditors and directors, a judge ruled.

headline: Amaranth’s Hunter Nets Big Return in July
abstract: Amaranth Advisors’ Brian Hunter is back in the news. But this time, it’s for the profits the commodity trader made for the hedge fund he advises.

headline: Finally, on Fox, a Lie Detector (Okay, It’s a Fictional One)
abstract: “Lie to Me” — a drama in development at Fox — received an endorsement this week with a 13-episode order and the addition of Tim Roth, most recently the star of “The Incredible Hulk,” as the lead character.

headline: Fannie Mae to Cut Dividend After Big Quarterly Loss
abstract: Fannie Mae, the battered mortgage-financing giant, cut its dividend by 80 percent after reporting its fourth-straight quarterly loss, one that vastly exceeded analyst expectations.

headline: The Almost Invisible Earbud
abstract: Arriva earbuds ($40), exclusively for the tiny iPod Shuffle. They may just be the best tech idea of the year.

headline: Citi’s Nikko Sale: A Harbinger of Bigger Deals to Come?
abstract: In what could be a sign of bigger moves to come, Citigroup‘s Nikko Citi Holdings will sell group investment firm Nikko Antfactory as soon as next month, said MarketWatch citing a report on the Web site of Japanese business daily Nikkei.

headline: Steve & Barry’s Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Steve & Barry’s, the purveyor of ultra-low-cost brands by the likes of Sarah Jessica Parker and Stephon Marbury, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Wednesday, the latest retailer to fall victim to the slumping economy.

headline: Deutsche, UBS See No Need For New Capital
abstract: Deutsche Bank and UBS have no need for fresh capital, the two banks said separately today. The news sent their shares higher for the first time in five days, Bloomberg reported.

headline: More Calls to Carve Up Citigroup
abstract: Citigroup may have beaten the Street’s expectations last week when it revealed a smaller-than-anticipated second-quarter loss, but some shareholders are still far from happy.

headline: Robbery in Valencia
abstract: This is another in an occasional series of F1 travel postings. I thought I would be able to lay off the subject after going overboard at the last race, in Budapest. But what’s going on here defies the imagination, I’d been wanting to say something, and I’ve had a special request to make mention of the organized petty crime that is going on here in Valencia.

headline: Human Tetris: It’s Time to Face the Hole
abstract: “Hole in the Wall” has already introduced a memorable catch-phrase to the reality TV canon.

headline: Who’s on ‘The Office’ Spin-Off? Not Amy Poehler
abstract: Try to follow this logic: the “Saturday Night Live” comedian Amy Poehler will star in a new NBC comedy, running alongside “The Office,” that will be produced by the creator of “The Office.”

headline: Are Cable Networks Cruisin’ for a Bruisin’?
abstract: Cable networks have fared better than other media entities amid the slowdown in advertising sales. But declines are coming, a media research firm predicted on Tuesday.

headline: Bain and Silver Lake Submit Offers for Huawei Unit
abstract: Private equity firms Bain Capital and Silver Lake have submitted formal bids for a piece of Huawei Technologies‘ mobile handset unit, Reuters reported.

headline: Republic Services Rebuffs Waste Management Bid
abstract: Garbage disposal company Republic Services rejected on Friday an unsolicited $6.19 billion takeover offer from rival Waste Management, saying it prefers an earlier deal with another suitor.

headline: Jil Sander Sold to Japanese Group
abstract: The fashion house Jil Sander, a maker of luxury ready-to-wear clothing for men and women, will be sold to a Japanese apparel group, the private equity firm that owns it said Monday.

headline: In 50-State Road Trip, ABC News Will Drive and USA Today Will Pick the Tunes
abstract: One of the enduring features of USA Today is “Across the USA,” its daily capsules of news from every state. Now the newspaper is partnering with ABC News on a venture to report from all 50 states in the final weeks before the presidential election. The joint project, called “50 States, 50 Days,” will begin on Sept. 15.

headline: MoFuse Raises Seed Capital
abstract: MoFuse, which hopes to make publishing content on mobile devices easy, has received an undisclosed amount of seed funding.

headline: Newspapers Worldwide (Minus U.S.) Oppose Google-Yahoo Deal
abstract: A worldwide association of newspapers asks regulators to block the Google Yahoo deal, even as its U.S.-based member says it has taken no position on it.

headline: Reading a Tea Leaf in the Take-Two Saga
abstract: Electronic Arts has hired Joele Frank, a specialist in public relations for mergers and acquisitions. But it’s unclear what her hiring means for the prospects of a deal between EA and Take-Two Interactive.

headline: Facebook Conference Report: News From Xobni, Zynga and iLike
abstract: Xobni, a handy Microsoft Outlook plug-in, is adding Facebook information to its service; Zynga, the social gaming network, raised $29 million from Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers; iLike introduces a joint service on Facebook with Rhapsody.

headline: New Animated Show ‘Cleveland’ Goes Multiethnic
abstract: “A ‘Family Guy’ spinoff show featuring the character of Cleveland Brown is mixing up its voice cast, ethnically speaking.”

headline: Hedge Funds Wither in July
abstract: The recovery of financial services stocks and the energy markets has hit some hedge funds in July, putting the $2 trillion industry in line for its worst year in two decades, MarketWatch said.

headline: Longs Investor Sees Merit in Rejected Walgreen Bid
abstract: Longs Drug Stores rebuffed a renewed takeover push by Walgreen, while Longs’ largest shareholder said it was willing to take the risk a deal with Walgreen could bring, to get the best price.

headline: Olympics: NBC’s ‘Online Ambition Is Valiant’
abstract: NBCOlympics served up 13.5 million video streams and recorded 291.1 million pages in the first four days of the Olympics.

headline: From Chase-WaMu Deal, a Bank to Rival BofA
abstract: The failure of Washington Mutual came 119 years to the day after its founding in 1889. It was no secret that the bank was having trouble. Banks and private equity firms had perused the bank’s books for weeks, but a deal did not materialize until it was seized by federal regulators.

headline: Origin Energy Announces Conoco Deal to Fend Off BG Bid
abstract: Origin Energy, fending off an $11 billion hostile bid from Britain’s BG Group, is to spin off its coalbed methane assets into a joint venture with U.S. oil major ConocoPhillips.

headline: Election 08: Palin Interview Draws Big Number for ABC
abstract: Here’s some more evidence that Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin is a subject of intense interest: she delivered the biggest audience that ABC’s evening newscast has seen in seven months.

headline: Apple Weighs In on the MobileMe Mess
abstract: Last Thursday, in my weekly e-column, I blasted Apple for the way it’s been handling the disastrous opening of its MobileMe service. Two weeks after launch, at least 20,000 customers still had no way to send or receive e-mail.

headline: Anatomy of a Disputed Drug-Store Deal
abstract: It’s the fifth day of CVS Caremark‘s $2.5 billion tender offer to acquire all of the outstanding shares of Longs Drug Stores.

headline: Severstal to Buy U.S. Coal Miner
abstract: Severstal, Russia’s biggest steelmaker, said it would buy United States-based PBS Coals in a $1.3 billion deal that will involve the purchase of Penfold Capital Acquisition Corporation.

headline: Siemens to Sue Former Chiefs
abstract: Siemens said it plans to sue two former chief executives and nine other ex-executives for what it considered supervisory failings in a bribery scandal that has cost the company millions in fines and damaged its reputation.

headline: Anheuser Approves $52 Billion Sale to InBev
abstract: Update: Anheuser’s board has approved the company’s sale to InBev for $52 billion.

headline: Barclays’ Diamond Eyes Potential U.S. Acquisitions
abstract: Barclays Capital president Bob Diamond said on Tuesday the bank would consider buying a U.S. wealth management company but is “highly unlikely” to bid for an investment bank.

headline: The Long-Term Questions for Apple
abstract: Investors are worried about Apple’s sales during a recession. The bigger question is how Apple handles the slowdown.

headline: Private Equity Circling Huawei Unit
abstract: Bain Capital, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Silver Lake and the buyout arm of Goldman Sachs are among the private equity funds that have made it to the next round of bidding for a significant stake in the mobile services unit of China’s Huawei, The Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with the auction.

headline: ‘Entourage’ Opens Doors for Wahlberg
abstract: “More or less a chronicle of Mr. Wahlberg’s own ascension as a Hollywood leading man and the enviably sybaritic life that has followed, ‘Entourage’ was an instant sensation.”

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Nobel Learning Investor Anticipates Milken Move
abstract: Is Michael R. Milken, the former junk bond king of the 1980s who was barred from the securities market, have renewed dreams of a hostile takeover?

headline: Yahoo and Icahn Settle Proxy Fight
abstract: Yahoo and Carl Icahn said Monday that they had reached a settlement that would keep most of Yahoo’s directors in place but add Mr. Icahn and two of his allies to the Web company’s board. The deal ends a fierce proxy feud, in which Mr. Icahn had been trying to install his own slate of directors and push Yahoo toward a deal with Microsoft.

headline: Discus Throwing? Done. Now, for Some Really Tough Jobs
abstract: Tonight on NBC: it’s “Deadliest Catch,” “Ax Men,” “Ice Road Truckers,” and other working-life reality shows all rolled into a 13-week competition.

headline: Ex-UBS Broker Files Whistleblower Suit
abstract: A former UBS broker who sold $30 million in auction-rate securities to Massachusetts towns and cities has filed a whistle-blower lawsuit against the investment company, alleging that it retaliated against him for cooperating with regulators and forced him to resign.

headline: Five Fall Season Debuts, on Hulu
abstract: NBC will premiere five debut episodes on the Internet a full week before they are broadcast on television.

headline: Agiliance Finesses $10 Million Funding Round
abstract: San Francisco’s Agiliance has raised a $10 million round of funding, Venture Beat reported. The startup offers IT tools to help companies comply with regulations and manage risk.

headline: The New Twist in the Hexion Story
abstract: The proposal by Huntsman shareholders to stump $500 million in no-interest financing to help close its disputed deal with Hexion — and Hexion’s swift and firm refusal — are fascinating new twists in the story, the Deal Professor writes.

headline: Another Record Low for an Evening Newscast
abstract: An evening newscast is recording record low ratings — and this week, it’s not the “CBS Evening News.”

headline: TPG Group to Take Dilution at WaMu, if Necessary
abstract: In a sign of the trouble at Washington Mutual, TPG and its investors have agreed to waive an agreement that would have forced the giant bank to make up any dilution they would face if the bank raised $500 million or more within 18 months, after the group invested $7 billion in April.

headline: The History of a Troubled Deal
abstract: Cleveland Cliffs’ recently filed registration statement about its troubled deal with Alpha Natural Resources still raises more questions than it answers.

headline: Amid Conference Halls and Keynote Speakers, a Rivalry Forms
abstract: Michael Arrington, founder the TechCrunch blog the co-organizer of TechCrunch50, a technology conference, has incited a bitter public dispute with a more established competitor, Demo, over the most ethical way to run such a conference.

headline: Did an Accounting Rule Fuel a Financial Crisis?
abstract: The pain in the financial industry has rocked the markets and stung shareholders — and some prominent names on Wall Street are suggesting that a well-intentioned accounting rule may be partly to blame.

headline: The Newest Disclosure: Not-Nice Words on the Internet
abstract: From DealBook colleague Floyd Norris on Notions on High and Low Finance:

headline: Red Hat Buys Seat at the Virtualization Table
abstract: From Bits: The virtualization software market just got even more crowded, thanks to Red Hat’s $107 million acquisition Thursday of Qumranet.

headline: BP Chief and Staff Face Removal From Russia
abstract: In another sign of Russia’s souring relationship with Western oil companies, foreign staff members of BP‘s joint venture in Russia, including the chief executive, will be required to leave the country later this month, some of them permanently, because their work permits were not renewed, The New York Times reported.

headline: The End of an Era at VMWare
abstract: From Bits: The exit this week of Mendel Rosenblum from VMware, along with his wife, former chief executive Diana Greene, marks the end of an era -– both for the company and virtualization software as a whole.

headline: Bumi of Indonesia Wins Takeover Battle
abstract: Bumi Resources, an Indonesian coal miner, has won its battle to acquire Australia’s Herald Resources, with a bid that values the target company at 563.5 million Australian dollars ($551 million). The final bid is 27 percent higher than Bumi’s original offer, FinanceAsia reported.

headline: One Video Game Union Is Celebrated, While Another Struggles to Get to the Altar
abstract: Activision shareholders approved the company’s merger with Vivendi’s Blizzard Entertainment Tuesday, as Electronic Arts started federal antitrust review of its hostile offer for Take Two Interactive.

headline: Clear Channel Settles Suit Againts Tribune
abstract: Clear Channel Communications said Wednesday it settled lawsuits against the Tribune Company and several former Clear Channel employees lured away by the newspaper publisher and broadcaster.

headline: CanWest Chief Mulls Buyout Bid
abstract: The chief executive of CanWest Global Communications, Leonard Asper, is considering taking the Canadian media company private, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: G.E. and Abu Dhabi to Form $8 Billion Fund
abstract: General Electric said Tuesday it has entered into an $8 billion joint venture with Abu Dhabi investment agency Mubadala Development with an initial focus on providing commercial finance in the Middle East and Africa. The two companies also plan to work together in the clean energy and water, aviation, and oil and gas sectors.

headline: South Korea to Review HSBC’s Bank Bid
abstract: South Korea’s financial regulator said Friday it might decide in September whether to approve HSBC Holdings‘ bid to buy Korea Exchange Bank, suggesting some progress in the long-running takeover saga.

headline: More Opposition to Google-Yahoo Deal
abstract: From Bits: On Sunday, the Association of National Advertisers, a giant trade group, said it objected to the Google-Yahoo advertising partnership.

headline: Insider Trading Suspected Ahead of 2 Deals
abstract: Federal regulators filed insider trading charges on Friday against unidentified individuals who are accused of making suspiciously well-timed purchases of call options in two companies before they announced multibillion-dollar mergers.

headline: Citi-Wachovia: a Banking Behemoth Is Born
abstract: Consolidation of the banking industry continues.

headline: Merrill May Write Down $6 Billion, Citi Analyst Says
abstract: Merrill Lynch may write down about $6 billion in the second quarter primarily driven by losses on high-grade collateralized debt obligations positions and monoline exposure, Citigroup analyst Prashant Bhatia wrote in a research report.

headline: Fluidigm Gives Up on Going Public
abstract: Fluidigm, a venture-backed biotech that planned to go public last week, withdrew its offering amid the market turmoil.

headline: Olympics: Nearly 40 Million Viewers for Phelps’s Final Swim
abstract: Saturday’s prime-time Olympics broadcast — featuring Michael Phelps’s eighth gold medal win — was NBC’s most-viewed Saturday program in 18 years.

headline: Olympics: In the Announcers’ Booth, but Not in Beijing
abstract: For NBC’s coverage of 13 Olympic sports, the announcers are not in Beijing, but in New York.

headline: Babcock & Brown Chairman and C.E.O. to Step Down
abstract: Babcock & Brown, the beleaguered Australian infrastructure investment firm, said Thursday that its chief executive and its chairman and founder would resign.

headline: Olympics Give Brian Williams a Bounce
abstract: “NBC Nightly News,” with the anchor Brian Williams in Beijing, received an Olympics bounce of two million viewers last week.

headline: Apollo Said to Raise $2 Billion to Buy Non-Performing Loans
abstract: Apollo Management is raising up to 1.1 billion pounds ($2 billion) to buy badly performing loans from European banks, in a move to cash in on possible steals, The Telegraph reported.

headline: The Electric Car Cometh
abstract: Behold the solar-paneled Prius. O.K. — that’s not what a solar-paneled Prius would look like, if one ever existed. (We found this mock-up at Jalopnik.com, where the fellas decided to have a little fun at Toyota’s expense.) According to the accompanying story, Toyota is supposedly looking to rig up some solar equipment in 2010 to … er … power the air conditioning. In any case, it got us thinking about the state of electric cars and hybrids, which is the subject of Saturday’s column.  Here are a few other, more realistic entries in the category of energy-efficient automobiles. Some of them even look pretty good …

headline: Microsoft, H.P. and Nike Announce Buyback Plans for Shares
abstract: Eager to project confidence in turbulent markets, Microsoft, Hewlett-Packard and Nike announced plans separately on Monday to buy back a combined $53 billion of their companies’ stock — a move, The New York Times’s Michael M. Grynbaum noted, that could benefit shareholders and attract new investors.

headline: Colombian Hostages Grant TV Interviews
abstract: The hostages who were rescued from a Colombian jungle last week are giving their first television interviews.

headline: NBC to Acquire British Production Agency for International Unit
abstract: NBC Universal said on Wednesday that it had signed an agreement to acquire Carnival Film and Television, an independent production agency in Britain, giving it a base of operations for international expansion.

headline: Can ‘Napster for Stocks’ Break the I.P.O. Drought?
abstract: Institutional investors use Liquidnet every trading day to move big blocks of stock. But will they jump at the chance of buying shares of the company itself?

headline: Merrill Analyst Adds to Goldman Bank Deal Chatter
abstract: Is Goldman Sachs mulling a move to buy a deposit-taking bank?

headline: Financial Chill May Hit Developing Countries
abstract: As Europe and Asia play down the need for an American-style bailout for their banks, The New York Times’s Mark Landler says the crisis may threaten a different class of countries: those in Eastern Europe, Latin America and Africa that depend on foreign capital and shoulder American-style trade deficits.

headline: Really. Not. Good.
abstract: An American contractor who just landed in Iraq took a wrong turn from the airport and found himself in a very bad place, but at least still breathing.

headline: Has Any Penny Stock Become a Big Company?
abstract: The previous post, on stealing a company, brought a claim that is common, but incorrect: that a major company used to be a penny stock. In this case, the claim was made for Intel.

headline: Donna Must Replicate: CW Orders a Full Season of ‘90210’
abstract: In a no-brainer move, the CW on Monday said it had ordered a full season of “90210,” the re-make of the popular 1990s drama set in Beverly Hills.

headline: A Convention Winner: Fox News
abstract: Viewers have been gravitating toward cable news, that always-on fountain of political opinion, to a degree not seen in previous election cycles, and the channel that has benefited the most is Fox News Channel.

headline: Global Regulations Need Bolstering, Britain’s F.S.A. Chief Says
abstract: Weaknesses in the regulation of the global financial system have been revealed during the recent credit crunch, the chairman of Britain’s Financial Services Authority said on Sunday.

headline: Dow Chemical to Buy Rohm and Haas for $15.3 Billion
abstract: Dow Chemical said Thursday that it has agreed to buy Rohm and Haas, the old-line specialty chemical maker, for about $15.3 billion in cash, one of the largest deals this year and one made with the help of Warren E. Buffett and the Kuwaiti government.

headline: DreamWorks Investor Kicks the Tires at MGM, Report Says
abstract: After inking a deal to invest in Steven Spielberg’s DreamWorks studio, India’s Reliance ADA Group is now in talks with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer about a potential buyout or equity investment, The New York Post reported.

headline: Early Results in CSX Fight: 4 Seats for Hedge Funds
abstract: The long-running drama over CSX drew closer to completion on Wednesday, as the independent inspector of the railroad operator’s shareholder vote said that a pair of activist hedge funds appears to have gained four seats on the company’s board.

headline: RAB Capital Proposes Lock-Down to Avoid Liquidation
abstract: RAB Capital, which recently removed its chief executive from his post, announced Wednesday that it wanted to freeze redemptions in an effort to restructure its flagship hedge fund, which has plunged in value by nearly half this year, with a 22 percent drop in August alone.

headline: Asleep on the Roof
abstract: Mudhafer al-Husaini is an Iraqi employee of The New York Times in Baghdad.

headline: $100 Says You Won’t Watch People Try to Solve Rubik’s Cube Underwater
abstract: Want to bet how many more weeks “Wanna Bet” will be on ABC?

headline: Merrill’s Fire Sale May Burn Other Firms
abstract: Will Merrill Lynch‘s latest mark-downs spell trouble for other investment banks? That was one big question on Wall Street after Monday’s surprise announcement that Merrill was selling a big pile of risky assets at a deep discount.

headline: As Deutsche Stumbles, Ackermann Calls for Industry Reform
abstract: Deutsche Bank chief Josef Ackermann, whose bank on Thursday announced a further $3.6 billion of write-downs for the second quarter, renewed calls for reforms in the financial sector in a piece appearing in The Financial Times.

headline: The Troop Debate: Dark Humor
abstract: Qassem H.J. is a newspaper cartoonist working in Iraq. He abbreviates his name to protect his identity. This is part of a week-long series of blog posts on the debate inside Iraq over the presence of American troops.

headline: Google Changes Home Page, Adding Link to Privacy Policy
abstract: Google has added the word “privacy” to its home page, bringing it into clear compliance with a California law that requires many Internet sites to have a link to their privacy policy on their home page.

headline: Thursday Ratings: ‘CSI’ On Top
abstract: CBS won the network television ratings race on Thursday thanks to a rerun of “CSI” and “Big Brother.”

headline: Big Bailout Plan Is Discussed in Washington
abstract: The head of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve began talks on Thursday with Congressional leaders on what could become the biggest bailout in United States history, Edmund L. Andrews of The New York Times reported.

headline: AT&T and Verizon Wireless Offer New Services for Friends
abstract: Verizon Wireless and AT&T announced new services that will allow customers to access a variety of social networking applications from their phones — with the prominent exception of Facebook.

headline: TCI Joins Push for TransAlta Deal
abstract: The Children’s Investment Fund Management has joined the fight to push Canadian power company TransAlta into a deal.

headline: Taylor Wimpey Fails to Find Cash; Finance Chief to Quit
abstract: Taylor Wimpey on Tuesday said it had failed to secure an emergency cash injection to repair its ailing balance sheet. The news led shares in Britain’s housebuilder sector to plummet, The Telegraph reported.

headline: Two Brokers Accused of Securities Fraud
abstract: The broker said the securities were as safe as cash. After all, he claimed, the outfit that issued them, Glacier Education Loan, bought student loans guaranteed by the federal government.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Storm Watch: TV Crews Await Daylight
abstract: As they studied radars and satellite maps of Hurricane Ike, TV meteorologists seemed in awe of the storm’s breadth.

headline: Awash in Uncertainty
abstract: One of the most inane pieces of market analysis that you regularly see goes something like, “Investors don’t like uncertainty.” When was the last time there was real certainty?

headline: S.E.C. Has New IDEA for Regulatory Filings
abstract: EDGAR, the computer database for filing documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission, is giving way to a new system that aims to let investors more easily analyze corporate reports and other financial information.

headline: KickFire Raises $20 Million
abstract: Kickfire, the maker of a database appliance that’s completely compatible with MySQL, has raised $20 million in a second round of funding.

headline: True Blu-ray Quality Via Satellite–or Not?
abstract: Satellite TV in high-definition as good as a Blue-ray disc? Be skeptical, say those who study compression algorithms and bit rates.

headline: Ad Pitch from Fox Business Network: No Olympics!
abstract: The Fox Business Network thinks that the hours after the markets close are prime times to challenge the entrenched business competitor CNBC — particularly now that the Olympics are under way, and CNBC is showing sports in those hours.

headline: An Alternative to Cable Chatter: Live Streams of Local Stations
abstract: In the aftermath of Hurricane Ike, four local stations in Houston used the Internet to extend their reach.

headline: Barclays Gives Lehman Energy Team a Lifeline
abstract: After taking over the North American assets of Lehman Brothers, Barclays Capital Inc. has hired the firm’s entire energy investment banking team in Houston.

headline: The Downfall of a California Dreamer
abstract: After his mortgage company nearly crashed a decade ago, Michael W. Perry set a new course. He bought a bank so the company, soon rechristened IndyMac Bank, would never run short of money again.

headline: Coming Soon: ‘Hope For Your Home’
abstract: The name of TLC’s newest housing television show is a comment on the gloomy economy.

headline: Will Fall’s Arrival Revive the I.P.O. Market?
abstract: Normally, the quiet summer season for the I.P.O. market gives way to a fresh burst of initial public offerings after Labor Day, as Wall Street wakes from its slumber. But, Fortune notes, these aren’t normal times, raising the question of whether the I.P.O. market won’t pull a Sleeping Beauty amd just stay asleep.

headline: Lehman in Bankruptcy; Merrill to Be Sold; A.I.G. Struggles
abstract: In one of the most dramatic days in Wall Street’s history, Merrill Lynch agreed to sell itself on Sunday to Bank of America for roughly $50 billion to avert a deepening financial crisis, while another prominent securities firm, Lehman Brothers, said it would seek bankruptcy protection and hurtled toward liquidation after it failed to find a buyer.

headline: Qwest Cables the Convention
abstract: Qwest has upgraded its network in Denver for the Democratic Party convention, adding 3,344 miles of single strands of fiber and 140 miles of copper wire and cable. The aggregate data capacity of Qwest’s network at the convention is about 50 billion bits per second, the company said.

headline: Delta Streamlines Check-In Software
abstract: Greatly streamlined check-in software debuted at the Delta kiosks in four big airports—Atlanta, Los Angeles, Orlando and New York’s JFK. By the end of this month, it will be installed on the rest of the airline’s 1,400 kiosks in 195 cities.

headline: New WSJ.com Builds on Its Community of Subscribers
abstract: The Wall Street Journal’s revamped Web site has new community features aimed at creating high-quality conversations among the business professionals who subscribe to it.

headline: ‘Life On Mars’ Is One Thing; TV In Britain Is Really Another World
abstract: Britain has proved to be a gold mine for television formats, as “Who Wants To Be A Millionaire,” “American Idol” and “The Office” have proven. But when producers try to adapt scripted formats, the transition can be tricky. British shows tend to live short lives, even if they are considered successes, while American shows often have longer life spans.

headline: The A.I.G. Rescue, in Their Own Words
abstract: From the American International Group, the giant insurer that was bailed out by an $85 billion loan from the Federal Reserve:

headline: Accel-KKR Closes on $600 Million Fund
abstract: Accel-KKR, the joint venture involving the venture capital firm Accel and the buyout shop Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, said that it had raised $600 million for its third-private equity fund, a third more than it had initially hoped to raise.

headline: Quadrangle’s Rattner on the Private Equity Drought
abstract: With finality now descending upon the Bell Canada and Penn National Gaming deals, nearly all of the remaining traces of the private equity boom that ended last summer have been swept away. But where does the leveraged buyout market go from here?

headline: In Troubled Times, Hedge Funds Go Macro
abstract: Hedge fund managers are looking to global macro funds to try to steer clear of the mess created by the credit crisis, while cautiously dipping into a small pool of more risky assets, a Reuters poll found.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell More of MSCI Stake
abstract: Morgan Stanley will sell half its remaining stake in MSCI, a company best known for its international stock indexes that went public last year, for about $850 million, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Web Filtering Moves to the Cloud
abstract: Zscaler, a new security company by a noted serial entrepreneur, brings Web filtering into the cloud, allowing employers to more easily manage which Web sites workers can visit and what they can download to the corporate network.

headline: Dark Humor
abstract: Qassem H.J. is a newspaper cartoonist working in Iraq. He abbreviates his name to protect his identity.

headline: Conventions: In a Repeat of 2004, Fox News Beats Broadcasters
abstract: On Tuesday, Fox News Channel was the most-watched network from 10 to 11 p.m.

headline: Seagate Tries Selling Drives on TV
abstract: Seagate, the disk drive maker, is trying to build up its brand name with its first television commercials aimed at consumers.

headline: Distressed Investor Sees Possibility of Depression
abstract: Forget recession — could the United States economy be headed for a depression?

headline: With Friends Like Carl Icahn….
abstract: This week’s column recounts an obscure fight involving a company that few people pay attention to anymore, XO Communications. Once a darling of the telecommunications set — just like its competitors Global Crossing and Level 3 — XO fell on hard times, just like, well, Global Crossing and Level 3. After filing for bankruptcy protection in 2003 — a filing that cost Teddy Forstmann’s private equity firm its entire $1.5 billion stake in the company — XO emerged with a new chairman and majority shareholder: none other than Carl Icahn.

headline: ‘Idol’s’ Cowell Voted Top Reality TV Villain
abstract: Reuters reports:

headline: New York Sun to Shut Down
abstract: The New York Sun, the six-year-old newspaper with a conservative mind-set, announced on Monday that it would close after publishing Tuesday’s issue.

headline: G.E., a Giant of Lending, Is Dragged Down Along With Banks
abstract: General Electric is best known as an industrial powerhouse, with manufacturing prowess in businesses that range from giant generators to jet engines to alternative energy technologies like wind mills and solar panels. Yet, the company is as much a bank as a blue-chip industrial company and last week found itself engulfed in the market turmoil, noted The New York Times’ Steve Lohr.

headline: Delta Said to Tap $1 Billion Loan Ahead of Northwest Deal
abstract: Delta Air Lines said it tapped a $1 billion loan ahead of its planned merger with Northwest Airlines and renegotiated its credit-card agreement to ensure revenue is turned over in a timely manner, the Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: G.E. to Buy $1 Billion in European Loans From Credit Suisse
abstract: General Electric‘s property investment arm said on Tuesdy that it has bought a portfolio of loans from Credit Suisse for 642 million euros ($1.01 billion).

headline: The Awakening: Protectors or Predators?
abstract: This report was written by an Iraqi employee of The New York Times. He is a Sunni who recently visited a Sunni area near Baghdad dominated by an Awakening Council, one of the groups of former insurgents who are being paid by the American military to guard their neighborhoods. His name and the area which he visited have been withheld for his own safety.

headline: F.B.I. Said to Investigate IndyMac for Fraud
abstract: The defunct IndyMac Bancorp is under investigation by the F.B.I. for possible fraud in home loans made to risky borrowers, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Not Nazi games, says dominatrix
abstract: Yesterday in my post I said that despite the victory by Max Mosley in his court case in London I still felt one problem remaining in the whole court case story: Why the key witness was absent and how the judge could truly come to the conclusion that this was not a Nazi game.

headline: Testimony About a U.S. Law in Russian Bank Case
abstract: A Russian court heard testimony on Monday from the author of an American anti-racketeering law, who argued in support of a novel legal theory that would allow the Russian government to apply the law in a $22 billion suit against the Bank of New York for its role in a money laundering scandal in the late 1990s.

headline: Wells Fargo Buys Century Bancshares
abstract: Wells Fargo has reached a deal to buy Dallas-based Century Bancshares in an all-stock transaction. Century, which is privately held, has $1.4 billion in assets and operations in Dallas-Fort Worth, and Texarkana, Texas and Arkansas.

headline: Six New TV Channels in India to Increase Murdoch’s Profile
abstract: Deepening the News Corporation‘s extensive presence in Indian media, the chairman, Rupert Murdoch, announced on Monday that the company would invest $100 million in six new regional television channels there, and he introduced a new Dow Jones index to track the

headline: Meet Our First “Daily Economist”
abstract: Introducing Edward L. Glaeser.

headline: Next ‘Bachelor’ Is ‘Bachelorette’ Reject
abstract: If the new man looking for love on ABC’s ‘The Bachelor’ looks familiar, that’s because he was rejected last season on ‘The Bachelorette.’

headline: Just 34 Hours Left For ‘Lost’
abstract: The Associated Press reports from Comic-Con:

headline: Report Says French Bank Trader’s Managers Were Negligent
abstract: Jérôme Kerviel, the former trader who lost Société Générale nearly 5 billion euros, or $7.2 billion, took advantage of his managers’ negligence to camouflage the unauthorized trades, according to a report by France’s financial regulators.

headline: Moody’s Shakes Up Management After CPDO Errors
abstract: Credit ratings agency Moody’s Investors Service said Tuesday it began disciplinary proceedings against workers involved in reviewing certain European debt ratings.

headline: When the Topic Is Obama, Writing Comedy Isn’t as Easy as It May Seem
abstract: Late-night television hosts depend on skewering political leaders for a healthy quotient of their nightly monologues, but Barack Obama doesn’t make it easy.

headline: Al Roker on The Weather Channel?
abstract: By this time next year, viewers may see the Weather Channel storm expert Jim Cantore on MSNBC and the “Today” weatherman Al Roker on cable.

headline: Slump Could Mirror 1990s, British Regulator Says
abstract: Britain’s banks should be prepared to cope with an economic downturn and a housing market slump that could mirror the recession in the early 1990s, said Hector Sants, the chief executive of the regulator known as the Financial Services Authority.

headline: S.E.C. Orders Hedge Funds to Turn Over Data
abstract: In an effort to determine whether any traders were involved in abusive short selling, the Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered more than two dozen hedge funds to turn over trading information, The Wall Street Journal said citing unnamed sources.

headline: A.I.G. Seeks $40 Billion in Fed Aid to Survive
abstract: Updated: The American International Group is seeking a $40 billion bridge loan from the Federal Reserve, as it faces a potential downgrade from credit ratings agencies that could spell its doom, a person briefed on the matter said Sunday night.

headline: Canadian Retailer Sold to U.S. Firm
abstract: The Hudson’s Bay Company, North America’s oldest name in retailing, will have some buildings gain the comparatively youthful banner of Lord & Taylor after its purchase on Wednesday by the private equity firm NRDC Equity Partners.

headline: Yahoo to Let Users Switch Off Customized Ads
abstract: Yahoo said it would allow users to turn off the customization of advertising on the pages of Yahoo.com, as such advertising comes under increased scrutiny.

headline: It’s Back to Sales at Yahoo
abstract: Joanne Bradford, the longtime sales chief at Microsoft, will take that job at Yahoo. The move suggests that display ads are regaining their importance at Yahoo.

headline: Wall Street and the Fed Seek a Financial Crisis Plan
abstract: As Lehman Brothers raced to find a buyer on Saturday, federal officials and Wall Street chieftains mapped out options to prevent an abrupt collapse of the crippled bank and arrest the downward spiral threatening other financial companies, The New York Times’s Vikas Bajaj reported on Saturday.

headline: The Wall Street Journal, R.I.P.
abstract: This is the week when it hit me. I really miss The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Whole Foods Asks Entire Appeals Court to Weigh In on F.T.C. Fight
abstract: Struggling to free itself from the mires of a court battle with the Federal Trade Commission, Whole Foods Market on Tuesday asked for the whole U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to examine a recent decision made on its deal for Wild Oats Markets.

headline: Naked Came the Speculators
abstract: Reining in the runaway freight train otherwise known as the credit default swap market is a rising priority for regulators who oversee banks and insurers. It’s a good thing, too, The New York Times’ Gretchen Morgenson writes, given the secretive nature of the swaps, the losses they are generating at some companies and the size of the market: $62 trillion in default insurance is outstanding, with a fair value of $2 trillion at the end of 2007.

headline: Will PBS’s Arts Commitment Include a Naked ‘Lear?’
abstract: Re-asserting its commitment to the performing arts, PBS has announced two big projects: a four-hour miniseries called “Latin Music USA” and a television version of “King Lear.”

headline: Tony Snow, A Camera-Ready Commentator, Dies
abstract: Tony Snow played out much of his life before television cameras.

headline: Law Firms Get Rated on Female Friendliness
abstract: A celebration in honor of the second annual survey of the country’s best law firms for women highlights progress, as well as trouble spots.

headline: Dr. Green Returns in ‘ER’ Flashback
abstract: Dr. Mark Greene is coming back to ‘ER.’

headline: And They Could Call It Frannie
abstract: An idea has been floating around Wall Street for several weeks, says Andrew Ross Sorkin: A merger of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. While Mr. Sorkin notes in his latest DealBook column that the idea of such a move is a long-shot — and not exactly a scintillating prospect — the economics, he argues, are compelling.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: A New Tool for Venture Philanthropists
abstract: Acumen Fund, Google and Salesforce.com introduce new software to help foundations measure the impact of grants.

headline: Cuomo Widens Auction-Rate Securities Inquiry
abstract: New York’s state attorney general office on Wednesday intensified its probe into auction-rate debt focusing on Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank, while issuing a warning to brokerages.

headline: Lehman’s Stock Hits 10-Year Low
abstract: Shares of Lehman Brothers have slumped to their lowest level in nearly a decade, as the smallest of Wall Street’s major investment banks keeps getting smaller.

headline: Inside the Explosion
abstract: Anwar J. Ali is an Iraqi employee of The New York Times in Baghdad.

headline: The Troop Debate: Stay
abstract: In Kirkuk, Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Suadad al-Salhy report that Kurds are increasingly using their control of the Iraqi police and their own secret police to further enhance their power.

headline: Mervyn’s Sues Private Equity Owners
abstract: Mervyn’s, the lower-cost retail chain, is accusing its private equity owners of essentially pilfering the company’s resources in a suit against the three private buyout shops and former parent Target.

headline: Big Names Back Satellite Project
abstract: A start-up with the goal of bring high-speed Internet access to poor countries around the world via satellite is prepping for takeoff, after snagging funding from heavy hitters, including Google, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Fallon To Practice ‘Late Night’ Online
abstract: Jimmy Fallon will rehearse “Late Night” on the Internet.

headline: Sun Valley Diary: Activision Chief on the Gaming Economy
abstract: Robert A. Kotick has a lot to celebrate. Earlier this week, the company he runs, Activision, merged with Vivendi‘s Blizzard Entertainment to create one of the biggest videogame giants around.

headline: In New Lawsuit, Anheuser Swings Hard at InBev
abstract: If ever there was any doubt that Anheuser-Busch intends to fight InBev tooth and nail, the American brewer’s lawsuit on Monday should dispel them.

headline: Same Zip Code, New Allure
abstract: “90210,” the reincarnated version of the 1990s series “Beverly Hills: 90210,” made an impressive debut in the ratings on Tuesday, setting a record for the CW as the highest rated premiere in the network’s 2-year history.

headline: TV Ad Spending to Set Record In Presidential Race
abstract: “The 2008 presidential race, which has already drawn a record number of dollars and voters, is poised to shatter another record: the amount of money spent on television advertisements.”

headline: SAC Electricity Traders Said to Leave Hedge Fund
abstract: SAC Capital Management has turned off the power on its electricity trading operations, as its four-member team has left the giant hedge fund, according to SparkSpread.com.

headline: Zut Alors! Hold That Headline
abstract: The champagne was chilled, the reporters were summoned, and the triumphant music was all but cued up.

headline: Citi Sees Opportunity in Asia-Pacific Hedge Funds
abstract: Citigroup expects to see double-digit growth in assets serviced by its recently expanded Asia-Pacific prime brokerage arm, as it seeks more business with global hedge funds setting up in the region.

headline: Emmys: Reality TV Goes From Strike Issue to Award Show Star
abstract: For reality television, this weekend’s Emmy ceremony promises heady and unprecedented attention.

headline: Quicksilver Bids Adieu to Rossignol
abstract: California surf-wear giant Quiksilver is leaving the slopes, saying Wednesday that it had agreed to sell Rossignol, its flagging winter sports equipment division, to Chartreuse & Mont Blanc in a $147 million deal.

headline: David Einhorn’s Gloomy Month
abstract: David Einhorn got a lot of attention this year — both positive and negative — with his ardent assertions that Lehman Brothers was in more pain than the firm was letting on.

headline: The Bush Administration’s $700 Billion Rescue Plan
abstract: The Bush administration is seeking $700 billion to set up a new fund to buy toxic mortgage-backed securities, the largest in U.S. history, according to a draft of the legislation obtained by The Associated Press.

headline: Freddie Mac Moves Closer to Share Sale
abstract: Freddie Mac won approval from regulators on Friday to sell the stock needed to overcome mounting losses, following a report in The Wall Street Journal that the mortgage finance company may seek $10 billion in a move to raise capital.

headline: Final Olympics Tally: 214 Million U.S. Viewers
abstract: The final numbers are in: a total of 214 million viewers, more than two-thirds of the United States population, watched at least a little bit of the Summer Olympics on the networks of NBC Universal.

headline: STMicroelectronics Sues Credit Suisse Over Securities
abstract: STMicroelectronics, a semiconductor company, sued the Credit Suisse Group on Wednesday, saying that the bank had defrauded STMicroelectronics by investing its cash in unauthorized and unsuitable investments.

headline: Royal Bank of Scotland Posts a Rare Loss
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group reported a half-year loss of 802 million pounds ($1.5 billion), its first loss in 40 years, because of 5.9 billion pounds (11.4 billion) in write-downs stemming from the American subprime credit crisis.

headline: CSL Buys Drugmaker for $3.1 Billion
abstract: CSL has agreed to buy Talecris Biotherapeutics for $3.1 billion in cash from Cerberus Capital Management and Ampersand Ventures, in what Bloomberg News said may be the biggest acquisition by an Australian health-care company.

headline: BAA May Be Broken Up
abstract: A government-imposed sale of at least one major British airport among those owned by BAA appeared to take a step closer to reality during the weekend.

headline: From CNBC to SAC Capital
abstract: Ron Insana made a big name for himself reporting and interviewing Wall Street hotshots as an anchor on CNBC. But so far, his foray into the hedge fund world hasn’t been such a hit. Nevertheless, Mr. Insana has reportedly landed a new position at one of the hedge-fund industry’s most prominent firms: SAC Capital.

headline: TherOx Plans $100 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Therox, a medical device company focused on treating oxygen-deprived tissue in heart-attack victims, said on Thursday it plans to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering.

headline: Long-Term Capital and Short-Term Memory
abstract: A financial firm borrows billions of dollars to make big bets on esoteric securities. Markets turn and the bets go sour. Overnight, the firm loses most of its money, and Wall Street suddenly shuns it. Fearing that its collapse could set off a full-scale market meltdown, the government intervenes and encourages private interests to bail it out.

headline: HireRight’s Alternative Deal Window Nearing Close
abstract: The window for HireRight to enter an alternative deal to its merger with U.S. Investigations Services is nearing its close, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: Ross Bets on Airline and Oil Prices
abstract: Wilbur Ross’s latest deal, an $80 million investment in the flailing Indian airline SpiceJet, announced on Tuesday, is hardly earth-shaking, but the idea behind it is typically contrarian.

headline: Warner Music Stock Outperforms Peers
abstract: Here’s some good news for Warner Music Group‘s long-suffering private equity backers: According to The New York Post, the music label, whose artists include R.E.M. and Green Day, is the year’s best-performing media stock.

headline: SunTrust Falls Amid Pessimism Over a Potential Deal
abstract: SunTrust Banks shares fell on Monday as a Citigroup analyst threw cold water on speculation that the Southeastern bank may be acquired by a larger player.

headline: Oracle Embraces H.P. in ‘Hardware’ Push
abstract: Oracle has teamed with Hewlett-Packard, rather than traditional partners Sun and Dell, on new data warehousing hardware.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Shapiro to Retire
abstract: The head of Morgan Stanley‘s commodities trading shop is stepping down, The New York Post reported. John Shapiro, who helped launch Morgan’s energy-trading operation, has told executives he plans to retire at the end of the year.

headline: UBS Beats Analyst Forecasts for Quarter
abstract: UBS surprised investors Friday by announcing that it expected to break even or make a small loss in the second quarter.

headline: Bain and Hellman Close to Deal for Lehman Unit, Reports Say
abstract: Private equity firms Bain Capital and Hellman & Friedman were closer to a deal on Sunday night to buy Lehman Brothers Holdings‘ prized Neuberger Berman unit, Reuters reported, citing two sources familiar with the situation.

headline: BP Puts $90 Million in Ethanol Venture
abstract: BP, the British oil giant, is ponying up $90 million to invest in Verenium, a U.S. producer of cellulosic ethanol, in a move that highlights the growing interest in next-generation ethanol, which is generated from nonfood feedstocks such as plant waste.

headline: Of Restatements and C-Suite Casualties
abstract: Chief executives and chief financial officers are increasingly likely to leave their posts — willingly or not — especially after an accounting restatement, according to a recent study by Audit Analytics.

headline: Abu Dhabi Bets Big on Hollywood
abstract: Last September, Abu Dhabi Media Company, an arm of the government in the city-state capital of the United Arab Emirates, reached a $1 billion deal to make movies and video games with Warner Brothers, the big Hollywood studio owned by Time Warner.

headline: The Buyout Boom’s Last Big Deal
abstract: It’s time to celebrate the first anniversary of the last gasp of the buyout boom.

headline: InBev Said to Begin Wide Syndication of Anheuser Deal Debt
abstract: As InBev starts up friendly talks with Anheuser-Busch, the Belgian brewer has kicked off syndicating the $45 billion in debt it needs to acquire the Budweiser maker.

headline: Presenting Young, in Interviews and on the Job
abstract: For those over 40 who feel their age is against them, some tips for appearing younger on interviews and on the job.

headline: Socialism, 21st Century Style
abstract: The government tonight nationalized the American International Group, the financial giant that could not find anyone else willing to lend it the billions of dollars it needed to stay afloat.

headline: Bonus Plan at Boscov’s Draws Fire
abstract: A court battle is brewing over the touchy subject of bonuses for executives at bankrupt companies.

headline: EOS Pulls in $2.5 Million Tranche in Financing Round
abstract: Environmental Operating Solutions, a water purification company based in Massachusetts, has closed a $5 million round of financing by closing a second $2.5 million tranche, according to VentureBeat.

headline: Out of Work on Wall Street
abstract: Some advice for those on Wall Street who might find themselves on the street.

headline: Cablevision Readies Its ‘Tivo In The Clouds’
abstract: One month after receiving an appeals court blessing for its so-called network DVR, Cablevision says the product will be available early in 2009. While most digital video recorders rely on an internal hard drive to record and preserve television episodes, the ones in Cablevision’s system record programs on the company’s centralized servers. The consumer still decides what to record, when to watch it and whether to skip the ads.

headline: For Microsoft, There’s No Place Like Enterprise
abstract: Steve Ballmer is charging after Apple and Google, which mainly sell to individuals. He may be ignoring the best path to continued sucess for Microsoft, enterprise customers.

headline: Wall Street Fastens Its Seatbelt, Preparing for This Week’s Ride
abstract: Frazzled traders and money managers spent an angst-filled weekend struggling to fathom the sweeping bailout the Bush administration proposed for financial institutions in the United States and what it will mean for the world’s markets.

headline: How TV Business Networks Covered the Bank Failures
abstract: From TV Decoder: The normally frenetic pace of TV business news took on a funereal tone Sunday night as CNBC and the Fox Business Network presented special reports about the tumultuous events on Wall Street.

headline: Apple Offers Networks More Price Options for TV Shows
abstract: NBC Universal will bring its television shows back to Apple’s iTunes service after the computer maker loosened its pricing structure.

headline: Liberty Media to Split Off Liberty Entertainment
abstract: Liberty Media Corp will spin off its stake in DirecTV Group and other assets into a publicly traded company.

headline: Sun Valley Diary: A Peek at the Agenda
abstract: For devotees of Allen & Company‘s annual confab who like to keep up with the official doings here in Sun Valley, we’ve procured an official schedule — against the wishes of the event’s organizers — for your information andperhaps even your amusement.

headline: TransAlta Mulls Buyout Bid
abstract: TransAlta, which posted tepid earnings results Thursday, said its special committee is still considering an unsolicited 7.7 billion Canadian dollar ($7.5 billion) buyout proposal from its largest shareholder.

headline: A.I.G.’s Bailout Terms Revealed
abstract: On Friday at 4:42 p.m., the insurance giant American International Group finally filed documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission setting forth the terms of its government loan and disclosing the interest that the government will have in it.

headline: Bunge to Buy a Tate & Lyle Sugar Unit
abstract: Only a week after it agreed to buy Corn Products for $4.4 billion, Bunge is striking up another sweet deal.

headline: Mini-Laptops Fuel PC Sales Growth
abstract: Notebook PCs in general are experiencing torrid growth, according to the latest quarterly PC sales statistics from the IDC research firm.

headline: Wachovia Hit With Bond Fund Suit
abstract: Things have gotten off to a bad start for Wachovia this week.

headline: Lehman’s Stock Slide Continues
abstract: Richard S. Fuld Jr. may have hoped that Wednesday’s conference call would stem the sell-off in Lehman Brothers‘ stock, but Wall Street is still running scared.

headline: C-Span, a Congressman and His Cellphone
abstract: When Congress adjourns, so do C-Span’s live broadcasts because the sole cameras that record the sessions of the Senate and the House of Representatives are controlled by the members of Congress.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.
