abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Should Waste Management Bag Its Bid for Republic?
abstract: Waste Management should put the lid on on its $6.73 billion bid for rival Republic Services, Breakingviews argues, saying that making the deal cost-effective would require steep cuts.

headline: NAB Could Acquire ABN’s Australia, New Zealand Businesses
abstract: National Australia Bank is in talks with ABN Amro to acquire its Australian and New Zealand wholesale and investment banking businesses in what would be a 1 billion Australian dollar ($962 million) deal, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Name That Camera!
abstract: Here are the specs. Guess the product.

headline: New Comfort for U.S. Acquirers Abroad?
abstract: Last month’s Justice Department opinion related to Halliburton may allow United States-based buyers of foreign firms to avoid risk under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act — but there’s a catch, Compliance Week reports.

headline: Cliff Asness Is Mad as Hell
abstract: My friend Cliff Asness, the managing partner of AQR, a $30 billion investment firm that specializes in market-neutral funds, is funny, biting, articulate, angry — and almost as opinionated as I am. When the “temporary” short-selling ban went into effect, I asked him if would share his thoughts on the matter here at Executive Suite. He said yes. This is his response (along with the world’s greatest disclosure, which I encourage you to read). I am hoping we hear from him semi-regularly as this crisis continues to unfold.

headline: The Crowd Stays in the Picture
abstract: A new survey shows that, when it comes to buying a new TV, size doesn’t seem to matter.

headline: Analyst Defends Merrill Amid Big Sell-Off
abstract: Have the troubles at Lehman Brothers caused investors to lose their heads?

headline: Where Did Wall Street Go Wrong?
abstract: A group of Wall Street executives released a report on Wednesday that outlined how the industry failed to foresee the financial meltdown of the last year and what companies can do to improve risk management.

headline: Escaping Bombs, But Not Accidents
abstract: Anwar Ali on a child who wasn’t caught up in a bomb or explosion, but could not escape a car accident.

headline: Merrill Names Pacific Rim Wealth Management Chief
abstract: Merrill Lynch has appointed Antony Hung as the firm’s head of Pacific Rim wealth management, FinanceAsia reported.

headline: Rescues Going On Everywhere
abstract: It’s bailout time.

headline: Itex Buys Intagio Assets
abstract: Bartering company Itex said it had inked a deal to buy Intagio‘s media trading system, its Intagio Media Services client base and its advertising credit assets for about $750,000.

headline: Notes from Silverstone
abstract: This looks like it will be a busy and interesting weekend in England. I’ve been in the paddock a bare 2 hours or so and already there have been three pieces of interesting, if not entirely unexpected news.

headline: AOL Says ‘Thanks’ but ‘No Thanks’ to Joan Rivers
abstract: Apparently, Joan Rivers is too hot for even parts of the Internet to handle. AOL, part of Time Warner, had intended to tout the comedian’s fashion coverage of last weekend’s Emmy Awards. The plan was for AOL to link to a video Ms. Rivers made for MyHollywood.com, an upstart entertainment Web site. AOL also planned to feature some of her zingers on its Emmy page.

headline: Italy Seeks to Broker Alitalia Rescue
abstract: The Italian government seemed to make progress Sunday in brokering a deal that would keep Alitalia flying after concerns over the weekend that the airline might have to ground flights because it could not get jet fuel, according to The New York Times’s Caroline Brothers.

headline: This Must Be the Place(ment)
abstract: The number of product placements on television declined in the first half of the year, according to a report, but the reason does not seem to be because the practice is falling out of favor.

headline: No-Short List Keeps Getting Longer
abstract: In the latest move to protect lenders and brokerages from bear raids, the New York Stock Exchange has banned short selling in that well-known financial firm, CVS Caremark.

headline: TA Associates and I.C.G. Book Gains on Creditex Deal
abstract: TA Associates and Internet Capital Group have walked away richer after signing a deal to sell Creditex Group, an interdealer credit derivative brokerage, to IntercontinentalExchange.

headline: National City’s Cash Infusion Is Approved
abstract: National City, a Midwestern regional bank battered by mortgage losses, has won stockholder approval to authorize new shares to allow for a $7 billion capital infusion, the bank said on Monday.

headline: Prudential Taps Former Man Group President as Chairman
abstract: British insurer Prudential has tapped hedge fund veteran Harvey McGrath as chairman, replacing David Clementi, who will retire at the end of the year.

headline: ‘Iconoclasts’ Lineup Set
abstract: What will be the topics when Archbishop Desmond Tutu of the Anglican Church of South Africa and the British entrepreneur Richard Branson are brought together by the Sundance Channel for a television taping?

headline: ‘ER’ Wants Clooney Cameo, but Actor Says He’s Not Coming Back
abstract: George Clooney hasn’t been tempted yet.

headline: Swiss Lawmakers Say UBS, Credit Suisse Need More Capital
abstract: Swiss authorities could require UBS and Credit Suisse to set aside an additional 70 billion Swiss francs ($68.29 billion) in capital, a newspaper reported on Sunday, citing lawmakers.

headline: Intel Capital Invests $37.7 Million in Sulfurcell
abstract: German thin-film solar cell manufacturer Sulfurcell closed on a $133.7 million round, which was led by Intel Capital with a $37.7 million contribution.

headline: VMAs: ‘On This Awards Show, the Awards Have Barely Mattered’
abstract: “They are red herrings in what has actually been, for 25 years, a reality show…”

headline: Goldman May Buy Distressed Assets With New Cash
abstract: Goldman Sachs doesn’t intend to let its newly-raised $10 billion burn a hole in its pocket. The Daily Telegraph reported that the $5 billion Goldman received from Warren Buffett and the further $5 billion from institutional investors will be used to buy assets either from the U.S. government’s planned $700 billion bail-out fund or from banks directly.

headline: New ‘Blood’ For HBO
abstract: Behind the scenes of “True Blood,” a forthcoming HBO series about a waitress and her vampire lover.

headline: Yahoo Said to Vet 2 for Board Seats
abstract: Yahoo is in the process of approving the appointments of former Viacom chief executive Frank Biondi and former Nextel chief executive John Chapple to its board and is expected to name the appointees by Friday, Reuters reported on Tuesday citing an unnamed source.

headline: Paulson Said to Concede on 2 Key Points of Bailout Plan
abstract: Two of the main points of contention over the Bush administration’s $700 billion financial bailout plan appear to have been settled — in its critics’ favor.

headline: Ex-Citi Executive Said to Blame Bank for Fund’s Flop
abstract: A former manager of a Citigroup hedge fund has filed a complaint with a British tribunal accusing the bank of causing his fund’s demise, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: And the Award for Best Picture Goes to… L.C.D.?
abstract: Sharp’s new LCD technology could make it a true rival to plasma for image quality.

headline: It’s Showtime for Yahoo
abstract: Yahoo won’t be facing a proxy fight at today’s annual shareholder meeting in San Jose, Calif. But there could still be some harsh words as investors weigh in on the Web company’s rejection of Microsoft‘s takeover bid earlier this year and ask how Jerry Yang, the company’s chief executive and co-founder, plans to reverse its sinking stock and profits.

headline: Analysts Said to Brace for $1.8 Billion Loss for Lehman
abstract: Some analysts are girding for a third-quarter loss of $1.8 billion or more from Lehman Brothers, instead of the modest profit they had previously expected, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Fuld Searches for a New Lifeline for Lehman
abstract: Lehman Brothers undeniably has a challenge ahead of it: boosting its capital base as it remains saddled with toxic mortgage assets. Now its chief executive is scrambling to find a solution without endangering the long-term health of the securities firm, The New York Post reported.

headline: Major Changes Are Suggested for Sirius XM Radio
abstract: The The ongoing struggles of Ford, General Motors and Chrysler aren’t making Mel Karmazin’s job any easier.

headline: Emmy Nominations: ‘The Wire’ Gets One Final Snub
abstract: The Associated Press reports:

headline: Google at Age 10
abstract: Google applied for incorporation 10 years ago. Where does the company stand today, especially compared to rival Microsoft? We take a look at the numbers.

headline: Waking Up With Soldiers
abstract: Suadad al-Salhy, an Iraqi reporter for The Times, writes about American soldiers searching her family’s home.

headline: JPMorgan’s Warning Casts Pall on Freddie’s Good News
abstract: JPMorgan Chase said the market value of its investments in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac preferred stock has dropped by half to $600 million this quarter, casting a pall on Freddie’s successful $2 billion debt offering.

headline: Korean Bank Confirms Talks About Lehman Deal
abstract: The head of Korea Development Bank said Tuesday that the state-owned lender is in discussions about potentially acquiring troubled U.S. investment bank Lehman Brothers as part of a larger investment group, the Associated Press reported. The statement came a little more than a week after reports that the Korean bank was interested in buying Lehman; at the time, a spokesman for the bank told The New York Times such reports were “erroneous.”

headline: Turkey — Is It East or West?
abstract: Anwar Ali, an Iraqi employee for The New York Times, took her first trip to Turkey, and did not find it much like home.

headline: Should G.E. Spin Off Its Financing Arm?
abstract: As The New York Times noted Monday, General Electric is as much a bank as a blue-chip industrial company and that dichotomy last week landed smack in the middle of the market turmoil surrounding financial companies.

headline: Tuesday’s Payday Uncertainties
abstract: Will the tight credit market make it a day of reckoning for many companies and their employees?

headline: Anheuser’s Profit Rises, Helped by Price Increases
abstract: Anheuser-Busch, which has agreed to be acquired by a rival Belgian brewery, InBev, reported higher quarterly profit on Wednesday, helped by price increases and the introduction of Bud Light Lime.

headline: Lawmakers Seek to Curb Speculators
abstract: Three members of Congress, armed with a new report that they say proves that excessive oil speculation is distorting consumer energy prices, are renewing their efforts to exclude many institutional investors from the nation’s commodity markets, according to The New York Times’s Diana B. Henriques.

headline: A Dwindling Audience for ‘Swingtown’
abstract: Friday’s episode of “Swingtown” attracted only 3.46 million viewers.

headline: Wednesday Ratings: ‘Talent’ Tops Again

headline: Darfur Protesters Are Heard on NBC’s ‘Today’
abstract: An activist group managed to (briefly) interrupt NBC’s “Today” show on Wednesday morning with a protest about the network’s coverage of Darfur, which the group contends has ebbed as the network’s broadcast of the Beijing Olympics approaches.

headline: Will Smartphones Inspire M&A?
abstract: As VMware, Microsoft and others make deals to gain server and desktop virtualization technology, The 451 Group looks at possible acquistions that could enable these or other buyers to prevail in another looming virtualization battleground: the smartphone.

headline: Goldman Opens Toronto Hedge Fund Office
abstract: Goldman Sachs has opened a hedge fund office in Toronto, according to the Ontario government.

headline: A Fund to Rival Those of Other Governments
abstract: The largest sovereign fund in the world has about $600 billion and is located in the oil-rich emirate of Abu Dhabi.

headline: Olympics: The Advertising Gold Medals
abstract: And the gold medals for Olympic advertising go to…

headline: AMB May Be Mulling Japanese Deals, Report Says
abstract: U.S. warehouse operator AMB Property will spend more than 200 billion yen ($1.84 billion) over the next four years to expand its distribution facilities in Japan and is considering acquisitions, a newspaper reported on Wednesday.

headline: A Fox Cameraman and Two Marines Are Wounded in Afghanistan
abstract: A cameraman for the Fox News Channel and two Marines were wounded in an insurgent attack in Afghanistan on Sunday.

headline: A Smaller Paycheck for Murdoch at News Corp.
abstract: The News Corporation reported compensation of $27.5 million for its chairman, Rupert Murdoch, for its 2008 fiscal year, 14 percent lower than the previous year.

headline: Sun Microsystems Hopes to Shake Up Storage Industry
abstract: Sun Microsystems is planning to release a new storage product, code-named FISHworks, to challenge market leaders EMC and NetApp. Sun is trying to hit them with the same strategy that low-cost server makers used to beat up Sun during the technology bust.

headline: Palin’s Bailout Statement Raises Questions
abstract: Did Sarah Palin know what she was talking about when she made her first major statement on domestic economic policy? Her apparent suggestion that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were costing taxpayers money has some scratching their heads.

headline: Court Rules Banks’ Fiduciary Duty Is to Clients, Not Shareholders
abstract: The federal appeals court in Chicago has ruled that investment banks advising merging companies do not automatically assume a fiduciary duty to the companies’ shareholders.

headline: As Treasury Chief Rallies Support, Democrats Set Bailout Conditions
abstract: As Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. blanketed the Sunday talk shows to promote the Bush administration’s $700 billion bailout package, Congressional Democrats began to set their own terms for a plan to rescue the nation’s financial institutions. Democrats hope to include greater legislative oversight of the Treasury Department, more direct assistance for homeowners and limits on the pay of top executives whose firms seek help, David M. Herszenhorn, Stephen Labaton and Mark Landler of The New York Times reported.

headline: Motorola Names Leader for Mobile Phone Unit
abstract: Motorola has tapped a semiconductor industry executive, Sanjay K. Jha of Qualcomm, to head the troubled mobile phone division, which it plans to spinoff as a separate company in 2009.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: AOL’s Luddites Love Their E-Mail More Than Google’s Geeks
abstract: Users of AOL’s mail service check their e-mail more frequently and spend more time on it than users of Google’s Gmail, according to comScore data.

headline: Emmy Nominations: HBO ‘Humbled A Bit’
abstract: “HBO, which muscled its way to Emmy glory in the past with series like ‘The Sopranos’ and ‘Sex and the City,’ was humbled a bit this season.”

headline: Regulator Said to Plan Capital Rules for UBS, Credit Suisse
abstract: Switzerland’s Federal Banking Commission has outlined plans to impose higher capital requirements on UBS and Credit Suisse in the wake of their massive losses in the credit crisis, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Olympics: Another Victory, This One a Little Closer, for NBC
abstract: Ratings for the Olympics dropped slightly on Wednesday although NBC’s coverage of the Games easily remained the most watched television programming on the night.

headline: Britian’s Imperial Agrees to Bid from Indian Rival
abstract: India’s biggest oil producer, ONGC, agreed on Tuesday to pay $2.6 billion for Imperial Energy of Britain, as India scrambles to meet the rising energy demands that come with an expanding economy.

headline: Clips: Cable Lessons, Leah Remini, Digital Sub-Channels
abstract: What lessons can broadcast television learn from cable? Also: classic television shows could find new life in the move to digital TV.

headline: De Beers and The Botswana Miracle
abstract: My column this Saturday tackles a hard-to-answer question: how much good can a company with a conscience really do? In the case at hand, the company is De Beers, which for nearly a century was an out-and-out monopolist that worked diligently (and successfully) to control the world’s supply of diamonds — and that, in the last decade, has had the kind of conversion experience you don’t often see in large corporations. While still a big, dominant player (it sells 40 percent of the world’s rough stones today), it competes quite happily in a market economy, where the goal is to expand the demand, not control supply. I did not know any of this until I started in on this column — it was quite the revelation to realize that De Beers had become a more “normal” company.

headline: Iraq Briefing
abstract: A selection of articles from many sources on Iraq. For more, see the Baghdad Bureau blog’s Google Reader Shared Items.

headline: Leighton Holdings to Raise $609 Million in Share Sale
abstract: Australia’s Leighton Holdings, the world’s largest contract miner, plans to raise 700 million Australian dollars ($609 million) selling shares to expand contract mining in India, Indonesia and Australia.

headline: Economic Roundup: July Housing Prices, Consumer Confidence
abstract: Housing prices fell in July, and the cities whose real estate backs a huge chunk of Wall Street’s “toxic securities” are still in major trouble. Consumer confidence numbers showed modest improvement.

headline: Warren Buffett and the Salomon Saga
abstract: Warren E. Buffett’s $5 billion investment in Goldman Sachs is being hailed as a major vote of confidence in Wall Street’s prospects. Since the credit crunch began last year, financial firms have gone cap in hand to many investors, including Mr. Buffett, seeking capital to shore up their tattered balance sheets.

headline: ABC Chief Talks About Jay Leno, Katherine Heigl, ‘Scrubs’
abstract: Stephen McPherson, the president of entertainment at ABC, spoke to reporters at the Television Critics Association press tour on Wednesday.

headline: Lehman and BlackRock Said to Discuss Asset Sale
abstract: Lehman Brothers, seeking to raise capital, is in talks to sell commercial real estate assets to a group including fund manager BlackRock, according to Bloomberg News.

abstract: Giuliani Partners, the firm run by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor, is planning an investment fund based on commercial and residential properties in New York and Washington, members of the venture told The New York Times last week.

headline: Credit Suisse Names New U.K. Chief Executive
abstract: James Leigh-Pemberton is set to be appointed chief executive of Credit Suisse‘s British operations, The Financial Times reported. The move is part of a reorganization by the Swiss banker which has cut the cost of its top management team in Europe by 30 percent.

headline: On Second Thought . . .
abstract: There are signs of market recovery this morning.

headline: CrowdFusion Said to Nab $3 Million
abstract: CrowdFusion, a web publishing start-up founded by former Weblogs chief, Brian Alvey, has landed about $3 million in its first round of funding, according to Paid.Content.org.

abstract: The gap between “Today” and “Good Morning America” is the widest it has been in four years.

abstract: Enterprise Acquisition, a special purchase acquisition company, announced Monday that it would take a majority stake in Workflow Management for $742 million, including debt.

headline: Noble Environmental Fleshes Out I.P.O. Plan
abstract: Noble Environmental Power, a developer of wind-powered energy projects, said that it will offer around 24.44 million common shares in its upcoming initial public offering.

headline: Alcatel-Lucent Chiefs to Step Down

headline: The Strange Case of the Google Stock Plunge
abstract: Google’s stock price mysteriously plunged only minutes before the closing bell on Tuesday, but Nasdaq said it was precipitated only by erroneous trade orders from another exchange.

headline: In an Ohio State of Mind
abstract: In light of Delaware’s dominance of takeover regulation, it is easy to forget that other states have their own, sometimes very different, takeover laws and procedures.

headline: Olympics: Overlapping Coverage On NBC’s Channels
abstract: It is almost difficult to fathom the NBC Universal viewing experience for the Summer Olympics.

AdWeek points out that Lotame, Media6 Degrees and ContextWeb have also gotten venture capitalists to open their wallets in recent months.

headline: Citi Reshuffles Its Capital Markets Group
abstract: Citigroup is embarking on yet another internal reorganization, this time appointing new global product and regional heads for its capital markets group. Read the full memo on DealBook.

headline: September Surprise
abstract: A September surprise hits the banking industry, as Congress rejects the political establishment view that a bailout is needed quickly.

headline: Wife-Swapping? Yawn.
abstract: CBS viewers seem to favor an elite police rescue force over a group of sexually experimental couples.

abstract: A new, free, Web service connects people who have chores to people who are seeking odd jobs.

abstract: In a deal that will eliminate a legal tussle, International Business Machines has agreed to buy Platform Solutions. The move also removes a potential competitor for I.B.M.’s mainframe business.

abstract: JPMorgan Chase is close to subleasing about 270,000 square feet of office space at 277 Park Ave. to France’s Natixis, as the banking giant moves its investment bank to Bear Stearns’s former headquarters, according to Real Estate Weekly.

abstract: MSNBC is shaking up its prime-time programming lineup, removing the long-time host –- and one-time general manager of the network — Dan Abrams from his 9 p.m. program and replacing him with Rachel Maddow.

abstract: The ongoing credit crisis has created an unprecedented opportunity in Germany for any bank that still has the money to think about expanding, MarketWatch reported.

abstract: Yahoo, Hewlett-Packard and Intel announced a global research venture Tuesday to advance cloud computing, stoking healthy competition with other research initiatives backed by other U.S. companies and universities.

headline: The Joys of Olympic Sponsorship
abstract: From Thursday’s Sports Business Journal. I especially love the last line. Tell me again why any company should pay millions of dollars to be an Olympic sponsor when a clever marketer like Nike can link itself to the Olympics without paying a penny? For its (reported) $40 million a year to be an Olympic sponsor, Adidas gets the right to dress the officials in the Olympic Village. Whoop-ee!

headline: The Bullish Case for Lehman Brothers
abstract: Lehman Brothers‘ wild ride continues.

headline: SNL Premiere: Obama Will Play Obama. Who Will Play Palin?
abstract: The most-talked-about premiere of the fall may be… a 34-year-old series. Leading up to its season premiere tomorrow, “Saturday Night Live” is earning the kind of buzz that new shows always strive for. It has guest stars: Michael Phelps and Barack Obama. abstract: Richard Grasso is on a roll.

abstract: BCE will defer its 294 million Canadian dollar ($290 million) second-quarter payout to investors as it attempts to make its $52 billion takeover more palatable to a group of lenders that are seeking more favorable terms on the deal’s financing, The Globe and Mail reported.

abstract: With Netflix shipping DVDs again after a three-day outage and offering affected customers a 15 percent discount, here are three lessons from the ordeal.

abstract: Stifel Financial and The Western and Southern Life Insurance have priced a public offering of an aggregate of 1.7 million shares of Stifel common stock at $45 per share, according to The St. Louis Business Journal.

abstract: Is Jeffery Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, feeling the heat in his space-age kitchen?

abstract: Michael Phelps will be a presenter at MTV’s 2008 Video Music Awards.

abstract: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac aren’t just getting a bailout — they also appear to be getting a big gift from the Internal Revenue Service.

abstract: Samsung Electronics, the South Korean consumer electronics giant, has made an unsolicited $5.85 billion cash offer for SanDisk, a Silicon Valley maker of flash memory cards that are critical components of popular devices like MP3 music players and digital cameras.

abstract: A series of financial scandals at major Dubai companies threatens to derail the Gulf Arab emirate’s ambitions to become an international business hub unless the government tackles corruption head on, analysts say.

headline: European Central Banks Say They’re Ready to Act
abstract: As European stock markets opened sharply down Monday, major central banks said that they were braced to intervene to stabilize money markets after the upheaval on Wall Street, The New York Times’s Carter Dougherty and Julia Werdigier reported.

headline: Joy of iPhone Tech
abstract: David Pogue loves the Joy of Tech cartoons.

abstract: The Web may seem ubiquitous to most of us, but its creator, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, keeps seeing its limitations. Now he wants to do something about them.

headline: Can Brazilian M&A Stay Hot?
abstract: Brazil is famous for its beaches, soccer idols and samba. But in deal-making circles, the country that gave the world caipirinhas and supermodel Gisele Bündchen is getting noticed for other reasons.

abstract: Richard S. Fuld Jr. was fed up being Wall Street’s punching bag.

headline: Pride Goeth Before a Fall
abstract: The Reserve Primary Fund — the original money market fund — broke the buck today. That means that investors in the fund are losing money, since the net asset value fell below $1. In money market funds, that is the sin to be avoided at all costs.

headline: S.E.C. Chair: Regulate Credit-Default Swaps Now
abstract: Credit-default swaps used to inhabit an arcane corner of Wall Street. Now, they are fast becoming part of the national vocabulary because of the role they have played in the government’s decisions to bail out certain financial firms.

abstract: ABC made some scheduling announcements Wednesday.

abstract: Updated: Wachovia has begun preliminary talks with Citigroup about a potential merger, people briefed on the matter said Friday afternoon.

abstract: Citigroup is out of the doghouse at Deutsche Bank.

abstract: China’s venture capital market had a brisk second quarter with a growth of 70 percent and 159 companies attracting investment.

abstract: — The New York Times: The Jewish Channel, newly available in the New York area, is finding an audience for “Rabbi’s Roundtable,” documentaries, films and other programming.

abstract: “MTV is doing the time warp,” Julie Bloom reports.

abstract: Roughly 24 million television viewers watched the Democratic convention Monday night, when Michelle Obama spoke about her husband and her family, according to Nielsen Media Research.

abstract: A working group of the International Monetary Fund said it reached a preliminary agreement on guidelines for sovereign wealth funds that invest abroad. It didn’t disclose specifics of the voluntary code of conduct, which is to be presented to I.M.F. members in October.

abstract: If it wears out, you can’t afford it.

headline: Former Drexel Chief Speaks About Lehman’s Fall
abstract: Before Lehman Brothers landed in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last week, the largest investment bank ever to fail was Drexel Burnham Lambert. Drexel was the broker-dealer that famously went belly up back in 1990 as bets it made in the junk-bond market went bad.

headline: BASF Said to Consider Major Acquisition
abstract: BASF, the German chemical giant, is reportedly considering a major acquisition, with United States-based W.R. Grace said to be a possible target, according to a report in The Financial Times Deutschland.

headline: ‘Project Runway’ on Lifetime Postponed; ’24’ Taking Time for Rewrites
abstract: Two schedule changes of note.

headline: So Who Exactly Is Watching Those Reruns of ‘NCIS?’
abstract: As the extraordinary Michael Phelps racked up his fourth and fifth gold medals in Beijing, NBC earned its highest ratings for a Tuesday in more than six years.

headline: Last Week’s Ratings: Pro Football Helps Carry NBC to Ratings Win
abstract: With most scripted series still in repeats and few new fall series unveiled yet, pro football drew the biggest audiences last week.

headline: Future of Weather Plus: ‘Undetermined’
abstract: How will NBC Weather Plus, the digital weather network, fit inside NBC Universal now that the company is acquiring the Weather Channel?

headline: Losing Jobs (And Elections?)
abstract: The employment report today should — but won’t — end any remaining debate about whether the United States is in recession. It is.

headline: NBC Considering Ensemble for ‘Meet the Press’
abstract: NBC is leaning toward an ensemble of hosts for “Meet the Press” that would be led by Chuck Todd, NBC’s political director, and include David Gregory, a correspondent and MSNBC anchor.

headline: I.B.M. Ups Its Bet on Business Recovery Services
abstract: I.B.M. is spending $300 million to build 13 data centers around the world, dedicated to helping corporate customers keep their businesses up and running despite power outages, natural disasters or political turmoil.

headline: Before That Sex Change, Think About Your Next Paycheck
abstract: A study finds that earnings for female-to-male transgender workers increase slightly following their gender transitions, while earnings for male-to-female transgender workers fall by nearly one-third.

headline: A Dark Mood Among Hedge Funds in London
abstract: The global credit crisis and the collapse of Lehman Brothers have punished all manner of hedge funds. But in London, where a number have already been closed, the retreat has a particular resonance, The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr. says.

headline: Man Accused of Extorting Blacksone Executive Blames Firm
abstract: A man accused of trying to extort millions of dollars from his son-in-law, an executive of the Blackstone Group, on Wednesday blamed the private equity firm for his “malicious” arrest and charges, Reuters reported.

headline: House Backs Oil Speculation Bill
abstract: Ignoring a presidential veto threat, the House on Thursday approved measures aimed at curbing speculation by hedge funds and others in oil and other commodity markets. It said federal regulators did not have the tools or manpower to track trading abuses.

headline: In Lazard Offering, Signs of Trouble?
abstract: Do Lazard bankers see trouble on the horizon? That’s what Breakingviews is pondering after the advisory firm’s executives filed to sell more than $300 million of stock in a secondary offering.

headline: The Basics, Part 1 of 500
abstract: The first of many tech tips you just assume everyone knows–but you’re wrong.

headline: Sun Valley Diary: The Yahoo-Google Power Table
abstract: The bar at The Lodge here in Sun Valley turned into a caption-writing contest for moguls Wednesday night: What was the group in the back talking about so intently?

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Campaign 08: Democratic Convention, Yes. Republicans, Not So Much
abstract: Here’s a surefire way to get your TV network some attention: promote coverage of one national party convention and refuse to cover the other.

headline: Judge Clears U.S. Request for UBS Clients’ Names
abstract: A federal judge cleared the way on Tuesday for prosecutors to force the Swiss banking giant UBS to turn over the names of wealthy clients as part of an investigation of its offshore private banking practices.

headline: Wall Street Says Thanks
abstract: Wall Street says thanks to Washington for helping create a mess.

headline: Trilliant Lines Up $40 Million in New Funding
abstract: Trilliant, a company that adds intelligence and communication capability to utility networks, will announce on Wednesday that it has raised $40 million in new funding from two venture capital funds, according to the San Jose Mercury News.

headline: Netbook Prices Are Now Falling
abstract: PC maker Acer saidit is cutting the price of its Aspire “netbook” to $349 from $399. It’s cutting the price of another netbook, the Linpus Linux Lite, to $329 from $379. The entire category of so-called netbooks – personal computers designed primarily for Internet use – may be headed over a price cliff, according to industry analysts.

headline: Chief’s Visa Is New Battleground in TNK-BP Feud
abstract: Russia’s migration service said Monday that Robert Dudley, the British chief executive of TNK-BP, was not allowed to work in Russia under his temporary visa. That was seen as increasing the chances that the joint venture’s co-owners, most of whom are Russian, could oust him.

headline: Venture Financing Drops for Youngest Companies as Older Ones Suck Up More Cash
abstract: In an ominous sign for Silicon Valley’s entrepreneurial machine, venture capital firms are cutting back on their investments in companies at their earliest stage of development and being forced to provide extra financing for later-stage companies that can’t leave the nest and go public.

headline: In Candidates, 2 Approaches to Wall Street
abstract: The crisis on Wall Street will leave the next president facing tough choices about how best to regulate the financial system, and although neither Senator Barack Obama nor Senator John McCain has yet offered a detailed plan, their records and the principles they have set out so far suggest they could come at the issue in very different ways, according to The New York Times’s Jackie Calmes.

headline: Fugitive Hedge Fund Manager Surrenders
abstract: Updated:Samuel Israel III, the hedge fund manager whose disappearance has sparked a manhunt for the convicted felon, has been arrested in southwestern Massachusetts, federal marshals said on Wednesday..

headline: Schaeffler Sweentens Bid for Continental
abstract: Schaeffler said it has raised its takeover offer for tires-to-brakes maker Continental to 70.12 euros ($111.68) per share from 69.37 euros previously.

headline: What’s the iPhone 3G Worth?
abstract: You can buy the Phone 3G without a contract, but it will cost you $600.

headline: Aptera Motors Drives Off With $24 Million
abstract: Aptera Motors, the electric car start-up that on Tuesday won funding from Google‘s philanthropic arm, announced Thursday that it has raised $24 million in a series C round.

headline: Energy Deals Are Small, but Potential Is Big
abstract: Lower energy prices don’t seem to be sparking major energy deals, at least not yet.

headline: V.C. Advice to Entrepreneurs: It’s Not All About the iPhone
abstract: The iPhone was the hot topic at MobileBeat, a cellphne industry conference, but venture capitalists advised mobile startups to build for all platforms.

headline: The Slow Going of Digital Voting
abstract: CSX has earned some brickbats over the past week for its unusual shareholder meeting last Wednesday.

headline: Merrill to Take New Charge as It Dumps Assets
abstract: Less than two weeks after announcing write-downs of $9.7 billion in its second-quarter, Merrill Lynch was back out with more on Monday.

headline: Arbel Raises $4.5 Million for Medical Devices
abstract: Arbel Medical, an Israeli start-up, has completed a $4.5 million second funding round, the company said in a press release. Arbel develops the next generation of medical equipment for removing tumors by freezing.

headline: Talon Latches Onto Lava World
abstract: In its first deal since launching last October, Talon Merchant Capital has gone retro. The private equity startup has acquired Lava World International, maker of 1960s teenager bedroom staple, the lava lamp.

headline: Court Tosses Out F.C.C. ‘Wardrobe Malfunction’ Fine
abstract: “A federal appeals court has thrown out a $550,000 fine against CBS Corp. for the 2004 Super Bowl halftime show that ended with Janet Jackson’s breast-baring ‘wardrobe malfunction.'”

headline: Swiss Re Buys Barclays Unit for $1.48 Billion
abstract: The world’s largest reinsurer Swiss Re agreed to buy Barclays‘ life insurance arm for 753 million pounds ($1.48 billion) to boost its Admin Re business in Britain.

headline: A Mortgage Rescue Strains Calculations
abstract: The proposed government rescue of the nation’s two mortgage finance giants should appear on the federal budget as a $25 billion expense, the independent Congressional Budget Office said on Tuesday, but officials conceded that there was no way to really know what, if anything, a bailout might cost taxpayers.

headline: Petersen Discusses ‘CSI’ Departure
abstract: William Petersen is leaving CBS’s long-running hit drama “CSI” after the 10th episode of the coming season.

headline: Carlyle May Open Its Wallet for Bailout Assets
abstract: The Carlye Group may soon start shopping around the financial services graveyard.

headline: Fear of Defaults After a Flurry of Apartment House Sales
abstract: The recent disclosure that the owners of Riverton Houses, a 1,228-unit apartment complex in Harlem, might default on their loan has shocked the real estate industry and raised fears about other apartment building deals from the not-so-distant past.

headline: Google Alumni Prepare Rival Search Engine
abstract: In her two years at Google, Anna Patterson helped design and build some of the pillars of the company’s search engine, including its large index of Web pages and some of the formulas it uses for ranking search results.

headline: The Real-Life Advertising-Industry Drama
abstract: As if “Mad Men” weren’t enough, the advertising industry can now entertain itself with the latest episode in what has become an international takeover feud.

headline: Natixis to Launch $5.9 Billion Rights Issue
abstract: Suffering losses brought on by the subprime crisis, Natixis said it would launch a 3.7 billion euro ($5.9bn) rights issue after revealing that it would make 1.5 billion in writedowns when it announces its first-half results next month, The Financial Times reported.

headline: U.S. Challenges Countrywide Financial Deal
abstract: The Justice Department has challenged an agreement that  Countrywide Financial reached in a bankruptcy court in Pittsburgh, saying it would make it harder to investigate and sue the mortgage lending giant.

headline: The iTunes Store: Profit Machine
abstract: Steve Jobs often says that the iTunes store is not much of a money maker in itself. But in fact it appears to have better profit margins than eBay or Amazon. And it’s quickly getting bigger too.

headline: Banker Charged With Rogue Trades Changes Lawyers
abstract: Jérôme Kerviel, the banker blamed for the world’s worst rogue trading scandal, has changed his legal team to focus on a more “aggressive” defense strategy, a spokeswoman for Mr. Kerviel told Reuters.

headline: Energy Recovery I.P.O. Excites Market
abstract: Energy Recovery, July’s first initial public offering, spiced up a generally barren market for new stocks on Wednesday. Shares of the company, which makes devices used in water desalination, were priced at $8.50 apiece, near the high end of the expected range of $7 to $9. They rose to $10 on the Nasdaq.

headline: New York Will Allow A.I.G. to Lend Itself $20 Billion
abstract: Gov. David Paterson of New York said on Monday that the state would allow the American International Group to borrow $20 billion from subsidiaries to bolster its capital as it faced potentially disastrous credit downgrades.

headline: Obama, Cuba and the Budweiser Battle
abstract: From the beginning, InBev‘s proposed takeover of Anheuser-Busch looked as much like a political fight as it did a corporate one. But while it began on the local level, the increasingly hostile battle of the brewers has grown to encompass presidential candidates and even the United States’s decades-old ring-fencing of Cuba.

headline: Stakebuilding in Britain’s Liberty Sparks Deal Chatter
abstract: Speculation that Liberty International, a London-based property group, would become the target of a bidding war intensified yesterday after two international shopping mall giants revealed that they had amassed significant stakes in the listed company.

headline: Does K.K.R. Still Want to Go Public?
abstract: Will Kohlberg Kravis Roberts still have its going-public moment in the spotlight?

headline: Google’s Little-Known Search Feature: One Box
abstract: Google’s new One Box feature is yet another reason to skip a site’s internal search features.

headline: Would You Take Strategic Advice From This Woman?
abstract: A propos of my column item on Saturday about Mark Penn, who just hired Karen Hughes to do “strategic communication” at his p.r. firm Burson-Marsteller, here is her e-mail introducing herself to her Burson colleagues. I’ll say this for her: she’s picked up corporate-speak awfully quickly. A “Burson person” indeed.

headline: A Few Have Talent, but Many of Us Watch
abstract: “America’s Got Talent” lifted NBC in the ratings on Tuesday as 12 million viewers tuned in to the talent competition from 9 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. NBC led the night overall, but by small margin, finishing third in the 8 p.m. time slot with “Celebrity Family Feud” (7 million) behind ABC’s “Wipeout” (9.4 million) and CBS’s “NCIS” repeat (8 million).

headline: Fannie Mae Chief Says He Likely Won’t Use Credit Line
abstract: The chief executive officer of mortgage finance giant Fannie Mae, Daniel Mudd, said on Thursday the company was unlikely to tap emergency credit measures that have been proposed for it by the Treasury department.

headline: Former London-Listed Bear Stearns Fund to Rename Itself
abstract: London-listed Bear Stearns Private Equity will be renamed JPMorgan Private Equity in an effort to reassure jittery investors, the manager of the $600 million unit told The Financial Times.

headline: More on Legal Issues After Layoffs
abstract: Taking another look at employees who blog disparagingly about former employers or start businesses in the face of non-compete agreements.

headline: Premier May Drop Just Group Bid
abstract: Premier Investments may drop its A$809 million ($778 million) hostile takeover bid for Australian specialty clothing retailer Just Group after the latter cut earnings forecasts, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: For Stocks, Worst Single-Day Drop in Two Decades
abstract: Even before the opening bell, Monday looked ugly.

headline: Fox Business Adds Journal Columnist
abstract: Fox Business announced that the Wall Street Journal personal technology columnist Walt Mossberg would be a regular contributor.

headline: Inside Sadr City: District Council Offices
abstract: The third installment of “Inside Sadr City” focuses on the importances of the local district councils.

headline: Breaking: Barclays Withdraws From Lehman Talks
abstract: Barclays withdrew from talks to buy Lehman Brothers early Sunday afternoon, casting yet more gloom on efforts to save the investment bank. Barclays, based in London, said it was unable to reach an agreement on credit guarantees for Lehman’s troubled assets.

headline: ‘Koppel on Discovery’ In China
abstract: Ted Koppel takes viewers beyond the oft-seen China in “Koppel on Discovery: The People’s Republic of Capitalism.”

headline: Silicon Alley Tells Wall Street: Send Us Your Résumés
abstract: Two venture capital firms are trying to lure some of the thousands of people laid off from Wall Street to work for technology start-ups.

headline: G.M.’s Hummer Attracts Gulf Investors
abstract: General Motors has received interest from two separate investors from the Arab Gulf region to buy its Hummer brand, the company’s Middle East chief told Reuters on Tuesday.

headline: Ackman May Push for Higher Longs Bid, Report Says
abstract: William Ackman’s big gain on his investment in Longs Drugs Stores is apparently not big enough, as the hedge fund manager is said to push for a higher takeover price for the pharmacy chain.

headline: Two Korean Companies Get I.P.O. Green Light
abstract: POSCO Engineering & Construction, the construction arm of steel giant POSCO, and Daewoo Capital have each been given a green light for initial public offerings in Seoul that will raise up to $1.48 billion in total, The Financial Times reported.

headline: ‘Radical Openness’ on the Google Phone — at Least for Now
abstract: Sergey Brin of Google and a T-Mobile executive discuss the openness of the Google phone — and its potential limits.

headline: For the Best TV Prices, Stay Online
abstract: Flat-screen prices are coming down; a quick survey found best prices are still online.

headline: Hasbro Notches Triple-Word Score Against Scrabulous With ‘Lawsuit’
abstract: Hasbro, the owner of Scrabble, has sued the creators of Scrabulous, the popular Scrabble-like game on Facebook.

headline: After the Bailout Vote, What Next?
abstract: Joe Nocera’s video reflections on the House’s rejection of the federal bailout plan.

headline: Brush Up on the Mandarin for ‘Table Tennis’ and ‘Triathlon’
abstract: ChinesePod, a popular podcast to help people learn Mandarin, is offering special lessons to teach Olympic terminology for this year’s games.

headline: Even Executives Are Becoming Free Agents
abstract: A new company, Epoch, acts as a broker between companies seeking interim executives and executives looking for flexible work arrangements.

headline: HBO Brings ‘Little Britain’ To U.S.
abstract: “Hit BBC television show ‘Little Britain’ is bringing its outrageous satirical humor to HBO in September.”

headline: Florida Deal for Everglades May Help Big Sugar
abstract: In June, Gov. Charlie Crist announced that Florida would buy one of the state’s two big sugar enterprises, the United States Sugar Corporation. He billed the purchase as a “jump-start” in the environmental restoration of the Everglades, which cane growers are accused of polluting with fertilizer runoff.

headline: IAC Lines Up Financing for Spinoffs
abstract: IAC/InterActiveCorp, the media and Internet conglomerate run by Barry Diller, said Friday that it priced $840 million in bonds and received $1.15 billion in bank commitments related to its planned break-up.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Who is Korea Development Bank?
abstract: As Lehman Brothers shares jumped on Friday on word that the Korea Development Bank may be interested in an investment, some may be asking: Who?

headline: Sun Valley Diary: If Found, Please Mail to 1211 Avenue of the Americas
abstract: Missing: One wedding ring belonging to Rupert Murdoch, the head of the News Corporation. More specifically, it’s the ring from his third marriage, to Wendi Deng.

headline: Federal Mortgage Success Stories
abstract: The government’s takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, The New York Times’s Eric Dash writes, is training a spotlight on a part of American financial system that rarely gets much attention: the vast network of federal agencies and quasi-governmental lenders that helps keep credit flowing through the economy.

headline: Shares Fall on Worries About Lehman
abstract: Stocks tumbled Tuesday after fresh concerns about the stability of Lehman Brothers touched off renewed jitters about the overall financial sector.

headline: European V.C. Firm Arrives Stateside
abstract: European venture capital firm Wellington Partners has opened a Silicon Valley office to help its investors and entrepreneurs bridge the cultural divide.

headline: Harbinger Bets Big on Rise in Times Co. Stock
abstract: Harbinger Capital Partners, one of two activist hedge funds that has sought to shake up The New York Times Company, may be calling a bottom to the newspaper company’s stock plunge.

headline: A Bittersweet Bankruptcy Filing for Mrs. Fields
abstract: Mrs. Fields Famous Brands, the private-equity-backed cookie retailer, said on Friday it plans to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to help restructure its business, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

headline: Mexico’s Slim Buys 6.4% Stake in The Times Co.
abstract: Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helú, the telecom mogul cited by Forbes as the world’s second-richest man, has acquired a 6.4 percent stake in The New York Times Company, according to a regulatory filing made late Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Chanticleer Adds Hooters Franchises
abstract: Investment firm Chanticleer Holdings has added 45 Hooters franchises to its portfolio via an agreement to acquire Texas Wings Inc. in a deal valued at $106 million, The Daily Deal reported.

headline: After Failed Bid, Alliant to Avoid Big Deals
abstract: Alliant Techsystems, a United States-based maker of rockets, said it is planning to steer clear of big acquisitions after the failure of its bid for a Canadian defense business.

headline: Amid Actors’ Guild Strife, Networks Are ‘Eerily Calm’
abstract: “Executives at the television networks seem eerily calm right now about the prospect of a strike by their actors,” Bill Carter reports in today’s New York Times.

headline: Restaurant Chain Auction Said to Be Off the Table
abstract: An auction of restaurant chain Dave & Buster’s may not have had enough flavor to continue. The process to sell the Wellspring Capital Management-owned group began early this year, but has been silent for the past several weeks, sources told The Daily Deal.

headline: Sovereign Funds May Turn Toward Asia
abstract: The trouble at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the U.S. mortgage finance companies, may discourage sovereign wealth funds from buying dollar-denominated assets, but the euro is not likely to be the main beneficiary, according to Reuters.

headline: Einhorn Expects More Pain Before a Recovery
abstract: David Einhorn, the hedge fund manager who gained fame by challenging Lehman Brothers on the state of its financial health, is looking for investments in distressed debt — but thinks prices have further to fall.

headline: Television Revenue Up, Operating Income Down At CBS
abstract: The local television stations of the CBS Corporation showed significant weakness in the second quarter of 2008.

headline: A.I.G.’s Building, After the Bailout
abstract: From City Room: Will the Federal Reserve’s $85 billion bailout of American International Group, one of the world’s largest insurers, affect its 1932 Art Deco headquarters in Lower Manhattan — or the relative lack of public access to it?

headline: The Mother of All Power Grabs
abstract: Talk about a blank check.

headline: Private Equity Investments in India’s Real Estate Sector Up 3%
abstract: Real estate and infrastructure management sector saw private equity deals worth $2.32 billion in the first half of 2008, The Hindu Business Line reported. The figure is nearly three percent higher than the comparable period last year.

headline: The Osbourne Variety Hour: Like ‘Sonny and Cher,’ But Less Crazy
abstract: Can Ozzy Osbourne’s family singlehandedly reinvent the variety show format? With Fox and FremantleMedia’s help, they’re going to try.

headline: Blackstone Executive Helps in Extortion Arrest
abstract: David Blitzer, a top European executive for the Blackstone Group, worked with authorities to organize a sting of his 71-year-old father in law and who had reportedly been trying to extort $11 million from the London-based private equity veteran.

headline: In Newest Crisis, Hedge Funds Face Chaos
abstract: Hedge funds usually thrive when markets turn volatile. But, as Landon Thomas Jr. wrote in The New York Times, even these fast-money investors are struggling to cope with the wild swings in the markets, raising concerns that some may not survive.

headline: Solazyme Said to Score $45 Million
abstract: Solazyme, which uses algae to produce biofuel and other products, has landed $45 million or more in fresh funding, according to VentureWire.

headline: Carbonite Steps Up the Competition in Online Backup
abstract: Carbonite, which provides online backup, raised a third round of venture funding to pay for advertising to consumers. It also partnered with Lenovo to preload its service on IdeaPad computers.

headline: Emmys: Venture Capital Rolls Out the Red Carpet for Joan and Melissa Rivers
abstract: Joan Rivers and Melissa Rivers have a new place to spout their colorful – some would say off color – commentary about the red carpet fashions of the stars.

headline: Wii Remote, Take Two
abstract: The new Wii MotionPlus is essentially an upgrade to the motion control mechanism of the Nintendo Wii, and will work with a new generation of games.

headline: Iceland, Germany Shore Up Two More Lenders
abstract: Two more European lenders were bailed out on Monday, as the credit crisis that has engulfed the United States financial sector goes increasingly global.

headline: ‘The Daily Show,’ Doing Much More Than ‘Throwing Spitballs’
abstract: Michiko Kakutani assesses the emergence of “The Daily Show” as a genuine cultural and political force.

headline: BNP Would Look to Buy Distressed U.S. Banks
abstract: BNP Paribas‘s chief executive, Baudouin Prot, said France’s largest bank would consider acquiring “distressed” banks in the United States, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: San Diego Sues Bank of America Over Foreclosures
abstract: San Diego’s city attorney said on Wednesday he filed a lawsuit against Bank of America and its Countrywide unit to prevent the mortgage lenders from foreclosing on homes in the city, which he aims to make a “foreclosure sanctuary.”

headline: Halcyon Executive Said to Leave
abstract: Former Goldman Sachs executive Steven Mandis has left his vice chairman post at Halcyon Asset Management, a $12 billion hedge fund, The New York Post reported, citing an investor letter.

headline: Bond Insurers Are Facing Downgrades
abstract: MBIA and the Ambac Financial Group may have their debt rankings cut several grades by the credit ratings company Moody’s Investors Service after Moody’s raised its forecast for losses on securities backed by subprime mortgages.

headline: Playing With Employee Perks
abstract: Perks at work — which ones matter so much that you’d leave if you couldn’t have them?

headline: Speculative Bets by Index Funds Didn’t Push Oil Prices Up, Report Says
abstract: Conventional wisdom in Washington holds that speculative money flooding into the market from index funds pushed up oil prices earlier this year.

headline: Why the Economy Needs Small Businesses
abstract: Against a backdrop of layoffs, small businesses can be engines for job creation.

headline: A.M.D. Sees Vindication for Deal in Graphics Card
abstract: Advanced Micro Devicesis planning to release on Tuesday a high-speed computer graphics card that it says offers proof that its troubled merger with ATI Technologies is finally paying off.

headline: Ex-Sowood Chief Making the Rounds, Report Says
abstract: One year after the implosion of his $3 billion hedge fund, Sowood Capital Management, Jeffrey Larson is trying to raise fresh capital for a new fund, Reuters reported.

headline: France’s Belvedere In Talks With Private Equity Firms
abstract: Belvedere, the French maker of Sobieski vodka, is in advanced talks with private equity funds about a stake sale as it seeks to emerge from creditor protection, its chief executive, Jacques Rouvroy, told Bloomberg News.

headline: More on Google and Day Care
abstract: This just in from the Dept. of Unintended Consequences: among the many, many pieces of e-mail I received about my column about Google’s day-care woes last week were several from parents who had children in other day-care centers in Silicon Valley, particularly the small handful that use the Reggio Emilia philosophy. Apparently, when Google was preparing to open its ultra-fancy center, The Woods, it aggressively recruited Reggio Emilia-trained day-care teachers from all over the Bay Area. It lured them with much higher salaries and the prospect of being full-fledged Google employees — status that more than a few Google engineers can’t claim.

headline: Bank of China Takes Stake in Rothschild Bank
abstract: Bank of China, the world’s fifth largest bank, said it was opening its wallet for a stake in the Rothschild banking dynasty.

headline: Settlement Over Sex Scenes in Grand Theft Auto Hits a Snag
abstract: A federal judge has put the brakes on a lawsuit filed over sex scenes buried in the video game Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas.

headline: The Airline Industry Whines
abstract: Hard to believe that with all its problems, the airline industry has the time to set up a Web site — and send out e-mail to just about everyone in America who has ever flown a plane — to complain about oil speculators. When I talked to the flack from the airline transport association, he basically blamed speculators for the cramped seats, the new charges for luggage, the foul meals, and just about everything else unpleasant about air travel. The cost of fuel this year, he added, is going to be more than $60 billion, compared to $40 billion-plus last year.

headline: Is the Government Tracking Us Through Our Cellphones? Lawsuit Seeks Answers.
abstract: Two civil liberties groups sued the U.S. Justice Department Tuesday to force the agency to disclose how and how often the government tracks individuals using their cell-phone data.

headline: Buffett Reports Further Dip in Profit
abstract: Even Warren E. Buffett, dubbed the Oracle of Omaha, is feeling the pain.

headline: Razgulay to Raise $233 Million in New Share Sale
abstract: Razgulay Group will aim raise as much as $233 million in a sale of new shares to repay debt and buy farmland and machinery, Bloomerg News reported.

headline: Lots of Buzz After Bush’s Wall Street Quip
abstract: President Bush’s recent comments about the current economic mess — “Wall Street got drunk,” he said, in what he thought were off-the-record remarks at a Houston fund-raiser — have inspired all kinds of commentary.

headline: Pressure Builds on Goldman’s Commodities Head
abstract: Some of the most stressful jobs in finance today are at Goldman Sachs, including those of the chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein and the president, Gary Cohn.

headline: Curious Office Gets Cash for Latest Start-Up
abstract: Curious Office, a start-up incubator, has landed $1.7 million in first-round financing for its latest venture, Pressplane, led by Second Avenue Partners and angel investors, including the former Expedia chief, Erik Blachford.

headline: Cracking Open the Anheuser Deal
abstract: If you are a Missouri politician, you no doubt feel a bit foolish this morning.

headline: Convictions of Supervisors at Stock Exchange Overturned
abstract: A federal appeals court dealt what was likely to be the final blow to the ill-fated prosecution of 15 New York Stock Exchange specialists Wednesday by overturning the securities fraud convictions of two of the floor supervisors.Skip to next paragraph

headline: U.S. Moves Toward International Accounting Rules
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission moved Wednesday to allow some large American companies to begin using international accounting standards as early as next year, and to require all American companies to do so by 2016.

abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack

abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the financial problems of American International Group referred incorrectly to the timing and participants at meetings at the New York Federal Reserve between Saturday, Sept. 13, and Monday, Sept. 15. Although there were indeed meetings that weekend, there was also a separate meeting on Monday to discuss financial aid for A.I.G. Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, was the only Wall Street chief executive who attended the Monday meeting, not the only chief executive who attended weekend meetings. Also, Henry M. Paulson Jr., the Treasury secretary, did not lead or attend the Monday meeting. (Both Mr. Blankfein and Mr. Paulson did attend the weekend meetings.).

abstract: More than 200 readers responded to David Pogue’s request for mail when he tested Earth Class Mail. Today, he shares some of your notes.

abstract: The day after she was rescued by Colombian commandos, Ingrid Betancourt stood on an airport tarmac and embraced the family she had not seen in six years.

headline: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com

headline: Israel Frees 198 Palestinians Before Rice Arrives for Talks
abstract: The release of 198 prisoners was aimed at bolstering the Palestinian president, hours before Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice arrived to nudge peace efforts forward.

abstract: Pope Benedict XVI arrived in Paris after saying he was “a messenger of peace and brotherhood” in this country that has long drawn sharp distinctions between church and state.

headline: Porsche Takes a Controlling Interest in VW
abstract: Porsche raised its stake in Volkswagen, a fellow German automaker, to more than 35 percent — a move that gave it effective control over Europe’s biggest carmaker.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: Treasury’s schedule of financing this week.

headline: BP Chief and Staff Face Removal From Russia
abstract: BP appeared to be in danger of losing control of its Russian joint venture after learning that local authorities had refused to issue work permits to critical expatriates on its staff.

headline: Syrians See an Economic Side to Peace
abstract: A profoundly uncertain economic future has created additional incentives for peace with Israel, which could help lure foreign investment by ending Syria’s pariah status in the West.

abstract: Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers rode similar paths of decline but had vastly different endgames.

Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: The Big Ten Wins…Sort Of
abstract: When last we left the new Big Ten Network — in a column I wrote last October — the new all-Big-Ten-sports-all-the-time network was in a long struggle to gain carriage with the big cable companies, starting with Comcast, Time Warner and Charter Communications. The cable guys were outraged because the Big Ten wanted a dollar per subscriber per month — nearly triple the price commanded by, say, CNN or the USA Network — and was further demanding a primo spot on extended basic, which is where everybody who starts a network wants to be. For their part, the cable companies wanted to relegate the Big Ten Network to a sports tier, where the fans who watched the games would also be the ones who pay for them. For the record, while I do not believe in a la carte cable pricing, I do think that sports should be treated as an exception: sports channels are so expensive — ESPN alone is some $3 a month a subscriber — that it is the single biggest reason your cable bill is so high. Putting sports channels on a sports tier makes sense, it seems to me.

headline: First, Let’s Kill All the Short-Sellers
abstract: So let’s see now. Mortgage lenders make tens of thousands, if not millions, of subprime loans to people who don’t have the ability to pay the money back. Wall Street institutions then buy the loans and package them into complex derivative securities, while the rating agencies give them triple-A ratings, which we now know that they knew amounted to a ticking time bomb. (E-mail will get you every time.) Then when it all goes to hell in a handbasket, who do they blame? Why, short-sellers of course!
