abstract: Cable networks revenue rose 9 percent at Time Warner last quarter.

headline: Rescue of Mortgage Giants Displays Paulson’s Clout
abstract: President Bush may be the nation’s first M.B.A. president, but when Mr. Bush and a small coterie of advisers met in the Oval Office last week to complete their plan to rescue the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, there was no question who was in charge, The New York Times’ Sheryl Gay Stolberg reports.

headline: Chrome’s Fine Print Isn’t as Scary as It Seems
abstract: A look at Google’s terms of service for its new Chrome browser has some users worried.

headline: Financier Starts Sentence in Prostitution Case
abstract: The bad news arrived by phone last week on Little St. James Island, the palm-fringed Xanadu in the Caribbean where Jeffrey E. Epstein, adviser to billionaires, lives in secluded splendor. Report to the Palm Beach County jail, the caller, Mr. Epstein’s lawyer, said.

headline: Japan’s MUFG to Buy Rest of UnionBanCal
abstract: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, one of Japan’s largest banks, reached a deal to buy the remaining part of UnionBanCal Corporation that it does not already own for about $3.5 billion, the two lenders said Monday.

headline: Lehman Brothers’ Shares Drop 11 Percent
abstract: Wall Street was abuzz on Monday with speculation that a rival firm was going to make a bid for Lehman Brothers at a substantial discount to its current price. The chatter sent shares of the embattled investment bank plummeting by 11 percent.

headline: Pioneer Previews Its New Blu-ray Player
abstract: The $2,200 Elite BDP-09FD Blu-ray player from Pioneer is not going to attract value customers. The unit, which will be available later this year, offers users the option to adjust 16 different picture variables to get the ultimate image, gold-plated connectors, plus a wide range of audio formats and high-bit-rate picture processing.

headline: Whole Foods Asks F.T.C. to Appoint Outside Judge for Hearing
abstract: Whole Foods Market asked the Federal Trade Commission not to appoint Thomas Rosch or any other commissioner to preside over the agency’s in-house proceeding against the grocer’s $565 million merger with rival Wild Oats Markets.

headline: Despite Economy, TV Sales Continue to Rise
abstract: Shipments of TVs to retailers in the United States and Canada jumped 28 percent year over year, to a total of 9.3 million units in the second quarter. Samsung not only continued to be the market leader in L.C.D. TVs, but also increased its share from 13.5 percent in the first quarter to 18.3 percent in the second. While Sony’s share decreased from 13.4 percent to 11.7 percent, it managed to hold on to the number two L.C.D. sales position. n

headline: Skechers Makes Another Run at Heelys
abstract: The footwear maker Skechers sweetened its unsolicited offer to buy Heelys on Wednesday, sending Heelys’ shares up sharply.

headline: Why Won’t China Trust Mr. Market?
abstract: So writes Jing Ulrich, who follows the Chinese equity market out of JP Morgan’s Hong Kong office, in her latest note to clients. (For the record: A shares are stocks of Chinese companies listed on the Shanghai exchange; H shares are Chinese stocks traded on the Hong Kong exchange.) Since last year, Ms. Ulrich has been following the steep decline of the Shanghai A shares — and the many steps the government has taken to stabilize the market. None have worked, and it is highly unlike that these two new proposals — reforming the stamp duty and establishing a “stabilizing fund” to help prop up the market — will work either.

headline: Merrill Lynch Shares Catch Lehman Bug
abstract: Merrill Lynch shares fell nearly 17 percent on Thursday as worries over Lehman Brothers‘ future raised questions on which investment bank may be next to face questions about its survival.

headline: Buffett Donates $2.05 Billion to Charities
abstract: Warren Buffett has given away 512,169 Class B shares of Berkshire Hathaway stock to three charitable foundations, in keeping with his plan to give away the bulk of his fortune, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Gerstner to Step Down as Carlyle’s Chairman
abstract: The Carlyle Group said on Tuesday that Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the former I.B.M. chief who became the private equity firm’s chairman five years ago, will step down from that post on Sept. 30.

headline: Cuomo Said to Inquire Into Fidelity Ties to Auction-Rate Sale
abstract: The New York attorney general’s office is probing the relationship between Fidelity Investments and Goldman Sachs in connection with the sale of auction-rate securities, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Mystery Suitor Considers Higher ImClone Bid
abstract: Has Carl Icahn rustled up a bidding war for ImClone Systems?

headline: A Call to Ease the Way for More Bank Mergers
abstract: Could consolidation be a panacea for the troubled US banking system?

headline: V.C.’s Invest $158 Million in India in Second Quarter
abstract: Venture capital funds invested $158 million in India during April to June, funds-tracker Venture Intelligence said on Tuesday. The total number of deals for the period came to 26, although no comparative data was given.

headline: Savings and Loan Crisis May Be Guide for Bank Bailout
abstract: Getting Congress to agree on a $700 billion financial bailout package might have seemed difficult, but the really hard work is only about to start, The New York Times’s Barry Meier writes.

headline: Citigroup in Final Moves to Shutter Tribeca Global, Report Says
abstract: Citigroup, the largest U.S. bank by assets, plans to close a $400 million convertible arbitrage fund in a final move to shut down its Tribeca Global Investments hedge fund, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: A Cone of External Swirl for Yahoo
abstract: Among the excuses Yahoo gave for sluggish revenue and disappointing profits in the second quarter were “headwinds” from a weak advertising market and “external swirl related to Microsoft.”

headline: Key ‘Idol’ Producer Is Departing
abstract: A key ‘American Idol’ producer who’s guided the top-rated TV show since its debut is leaving.

headline: CNN Tackles ‘The Most Complex Story In America’
abstract: In today’s New York Times, Felicia Lee writes about CNN’s two-night miniseries “Black in America.” It begins with “The Black Woman and Family” Wednesday at 9 p.m. and continues with “The Black Man” on Thursday.

headline: Hedge Funds Post Worst Performance in 18 Years
abstract: Hedge funds have suffered their worst first-half since at least 1990 as the credit crunch took a heavy toll on some managers, MarketWatch reported citing data compiled by industry tracker Hedge Fund Research.

headline: Time Warner Readies AOL Units Sale, Report Says
abstract: Time Warner has finished preparing to separate AOL’s dial-up Internet business from its advertising and content unit, as the media conglomerate makes plans to potentially sell one or both operations, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.

headline: HSBC to Cut 1,100 Jobs
abstract: Global bank HSBC Holdings is cutting 1,100 jobs in its investment banking operation, or 4 percent of the unit’s total, as it weathers the global financial crisis.

headline: Steve & Barry’s Said to Prepare Liquidation Plans
abstract: Retailer Steve & Barry’s is readying plans to close more than 100 of its stores, and is contemplating a full liquidation should it not find emergency financing, The Wall Street Journal reported on Monday.

headline: Dan Alpert Dissects the Bailout Bill
abstract: Daniel Alpert, a managing director of Westwood Captial, whose critique of the original Paulson plan I posted last week, is back as a guest blogger with another smart, biting critique. This time, he is tackling the bill that emerged Sunday night. Here are his thoughts.

headline: Square Enix Withdraws Bid for Tecmo
abstract: Square Enix, the Japanese video-game maker, scrapped a takeover bid for software developer Tecmo after its offer was rebuffed.

headline: Westwood’s David Alpert Is Very Angry, Too
abstract: From Executive Suite: The Treasury is asking us to step into a distorted world that makes little sense, based on trust and fear, with a plan that is in parts indefensible, argues David Alpert of Westwood Capital.

headline: Olympics: Finally, An Excuse To Cover China
abstract: NBC isn’t the only network catching the Olympic fever this month.

headline: G.M. Is ‘Urgently’ Trying to Sell Hummer
abstract: General Motors plans to have inked a deal to sell its Hummer brand by early 2009, the automaker’s chief operating officer Fritz Henderson said Wednesday.

headline: Counting the Cash for Lehman’s Chief
abstract: So far, Richard S. Fuld Jr. has avoided the fate of E. Stanley O’Neal and Charles O. Prince III, two other Wall Street chiefs shown the door after their firms posted huge losses. But as shares of Lehman Brothers continued to swoon on Thursday, it was clearly a make-or-break moment in his long tenure as Lehman’s chief.

headline: An Alternative to Armageddon
abstract: It is easy to see why investors freaked out when the House of Representatives drove a stake through the Bush administration’s $700 billion plan to re-animate the banking industry, Breakingviews says. The demise, it says, of Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson’s Troubled Asset Relief Program is certain to cause more pain – and not just for Wall Street fat cats.

headline: Big Financiers Start Lobbying for Wider Aid
abstract: Even as policy makers worked on details of a $700 billion bailout of the financial industry, Wall Street began looking for ways to profit from it, according to The New York Times’ Jenny Anderson, Vikas Bajaj and Leslie Wayne.

headline: Investors Turn Gaze to A.I.G.
abstract: Investors skittish about further losses in the financial industry have pounced on the American International Group, the beleaguered insurance company that has reported some of the biggest losses in the spreading credit crisis, The New York Times’s Mary Williams Walsh and Jonathan D. Glater report.

headline: McAfee’s Growing Enterprise Empire
abstract: McAfee‘s move to buy Secure Computing nearly completes the enterprise-security mosaic that McAfee is trying to create, but it also raises a question, The 451 Group says: How well can it integrate all of these far-flung pieces?

headline: New Season: ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Returns; ‘Worst Week’ Debuts
abstract: With the formal start of the fall TV season, new episodes are back on ABC, NBC and CBS.

headline: Henry Paulson’s Frankenstein
abstract: This is how a federal bailout works these days.

headline: Asia Rethinks American Investments Amid Market Upheaval
abstract: Tremors from Wall Street are rattling Asian confidence, leading many investors to question the wisdom of being invested in the United States to the tune of trillions of dollars, according to The New York Times’s Keith Bradsher.

headline: Olympic Trials and ‘Dateline’ Are Popular, but ’60 Minutes’ Holds Sway
abstract: For the third consecutive Sunday, NBC led in the ratings among adults 18 to 49 thanks to coverage of the U.S. Olympic trials followed by “Dateline.”

headline: Managing the Bailout — Gross Would Do It for Nothing
abstract: One of the chief concerns about the Treasury Department’s $700 billion bailout plan is that the same Wall Street firms that helped create the crisis could make a killing cleaning it up.

headline: Banks Borrowed $48 Billion a Day as Crisis Mounted
abstract: American financial institutions borrowed a record $47.97 billion a day, on average, from the Federal Reserve in the latest week in a scramble for cash as the global credit crisis deepened, Federal Reserve data showed on Thursday.

headline: Olympics: The Most-Viewed TV Event Ever
abstract: The Beijing Olympics will be remembered by media executives as the most-viewed event in United States television history.

headline: Bristol-Myers Bids $4.5 Billion for ImClone
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb said on Thursday that it is offering $4.5 billion in cash for ImClone Systems, the drug maker that Carl Icahn, the activist investor, took control of two years ago after an intense proxy fight.

headline: Iraq Briefing
abstract: A selection of articles from many sources on Iraq. For more, see the Baghdad Bureau blog’s Google Reader Shared Items.

headline: Revisiting Moral Hazard
abstract: Moral hazard is often misunderstood, rarer than thought, and feared more than necessary, in the view of one economist, who finds little moral hazard in the recent government interventions.

headline: Loeb Sounds Off on S.E.C.’s Rumor-Mongering Inquiry
abstract: Daniel S. Loeb has never been shy about committing his thoughts to paper. In an letter to investors sent last month, he lets them know how he feels about recent actions by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Sun Valley: Lights, Camera, Money
abstract: For years, the Allen & Company media conference in Sun Valley, Ida. was a time for media moguls to kick back, talk with their fellow executives — and maybe even strike a deal.

headline: Fluidigm Picks Black Week for I.P.O.
abstract: Fluidigm, it appears, hasn’t picked a particularly auspicious week to launch its initial public offering.

headline: Ackman’s Modest Plan for Fannie and Freddie
abstract: The bleeding at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac continued on Tuesday, with the stocks of both mortgage giants down by as much as 30 percent. The movement of both stocks suggest that investors weren’t assuaged by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson’s plan to recapitalize the two government-sponsored companies.

headline: Restructuring for London Office Debt Is Discussed
abstract: Fidelity Investments is planning an investor meeting to discuss a possible restructuring of defaulted debt on Plantation Place, the London office building bought for a record 527 million pounds in 2006, a deal then worth $918 million.

headline: Is Wachovia’s Management Shake-Up Over?
abstract: Wachovia‘s chief executive indicated to Wall Street analysts Monday that the recent shake-up in the management was over and that he was close to finding a new finance chief, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: TPG’s WaMu Loss Is a Bitter Pill for Private Equity
abstract: David Bonderman’s reversal of fortune is hardly one of the most dramatic on Wall Street, but it is one of the most startling.

headline: In Russian Conflict, Will M&A Be a Casualty?
abstract: With the geopolitical situation growing more strained by the hour, Wall Street is taking a new look at the risks of doing business in Russia.

headline: Fernando has a vision
abstract: The first practice session this morning was marked by the extraordinary moment in which Fernando Alonso’s car spat oil out on the circuit and the driver went off the track and out of the session, leaving, nevertheless, oil on the track. And then who should show up a few moments later but the leader of the championship, Felipe Massa, who drove his Ferrari onto the oil and slid off the track to run violently into the tire barrier. Massa was lucky he was not hurt, but the Ferrari did not look so good.

headline: A Cool August for I.P.O.s
abstract: This August has been the cruelest month for initial public offerings across the globe, at least since data provider Dealogic began tracking them in 1995.

headline: Olympics: Ads for a Female Audience
abstract: The Summer Olympics are reaching a large female audience, representing an anomaly for TV sports.

headline: Central Banks Pump Cash Into Market
abstract: The Federal Reserve, the European Central Bank, the Bank of Japan and other central banks significantly escalated the assistance offered to global money markets on Thursday, coordinating efforts to ease monetary constraints stemming from the turmoil emanating from Wall Street, The New York Times’s Matthew Saltmarsh reported on Thursday.

headline: Windstream Renews Deal Chatter
abstract: Telecommunications provider Windstream, which has been at center of speculation about consolidation in the sector, added fuel to the fire on Friday, saying it viewed consolidation as an important part of its strategy.

headline: Barclays in Talks for Lehman Assets
abstract: Barclays confirmed on Tuesday that it was in talks with Lehman Brothers about “the possible acquisition” of some assets at the American bank, which filed for bankruptcy protection Monday as the financial crisis bit deeper and sent world markets into a tailspin, according to The New York Times’s Landon Thomas Jr.

headline: U.S. Lifts a Policy in Corporate Crime Cases
abstract: The Justice Department announced on Thursday that it was backing away from the practice of pressing companies to share secrets with prosecutors and not pay the legal fees of employees accused of crimes. The shift came on the same day that a federal appeals court upheld a decision throwing out the criminal charges in a case where the tactics had been used.

headline: Lehman’s Fuld Said to Have Turned to G.E. for Help
abstract: Lehman Brothers chief executive Richard S. Fuld Jr. reached out to General Electric head Jeffrey Immelt about making an investment in the embattled bank prior to its collapse, The New York Post reported, citing unnamed sources.

headline: A Chat With an Olympic Icon, Eric Heiden
abstract: A conversation with 1980 Olympic champion, Eric Heiden, about his post-Olympic career as an orthopedic surgeon.

headline: When I.P.O.’s Dry Up
abstract: This year is shaping up to be a barren one for initial public offerings, much to the dismay of venture capitalists, who have fewer options for harvesting their investments, not to mention the Wall Street underwriters that are twiddling their thumbs. Investment Dealers’ Digest looks at the causes of the drought and its broader effects.

headline: Weekly Ratings: ‘America’s Got Talent’ Still In First Place
abstract: The Associated Press sums up last week’s ratings:

headline: Fortress Shows Steep Drop in Profit
abstract: Fortress Investment Group, the first of the big American alternative-asset managers to go public last year, reported $58 million in second-quarter pre-tax earnings on Thursday, though the hedge fund and private equity firm pulled in far less new capital than it did at the same time last year.

headline: GridPoint Takes $120 Million
abstract: GridPoint, a provider of smart-grid technology, has snagged a hefty $120 million in its fifth-round funding.

headline: Merrill Said to Seriously Consider Sale of Holdings
abstract: Building on existing speculation that Merrill Lynch could be forced to sell key assets such as stakes in Bloomberg L.P. and BlackRock, The New York Post reported that a Merrill source said everything is indeed on the table.

headline: UBS to Expand in Middle East
abstract: UBS has received a license to operate in Saudi Arabia and will offer investment banking, asset management and wealth management services there. Further, it will more than double its investment banking team in the Middle East by the end of the year, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Olympics: NBC Passes One Billion in Ad Sales
abstract: One day before NBC Universal begins broadcasting the Summer Olympic Games, the company said that advertising sales had surpassed the $1 billion mark.

headline: Bayan Said to Consider $679 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Bayan Resources will forge ahead with its initial public offering despite the cancelation of several other Asian listings over the past few days, FinanceAsia reported.

headline: MTN Extends Reliance Merger Talks
abstract: MTN has agreed to extend exclusive talks with Reliance Communications stemming, for now, speculation that the deal might fall apart due to a case of sibling rivalry inside Reliance, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Hedge Fund Investors Suit Against UBS Dismissed
abstract: A lawsuit against UBS alleging that the Swiss bank engaged in fraud related to holdings of a fund in loss-making company Endwave was dismissed by a New York Supreme Court judge, court documents showed.

headline: Sequoia Goes to Bat for Challenge Games
abstract: Challenge Games has received $4.5 million from Sequoia Capital and announced a multi-year licensing deal with MLB Advanced Media, the interactive media and Internet company of Major League Baseball.

headline: Big Hedge Funds Said to Post Big Losses
abstract: According to figures compiled by HSBC Private Bank, some familiar names among activist hedge funds are suffering a record worst start to the year, with some losses posted at more than 20 percent.

headline: Viacom and Google in Stalemate Over Shielding Identities in YouTube Data
abstract: Google and Viacom are still wrangling over how much to shield identifying information about individual users in YouTube data that Viacom wants in a copyright dispute.

headline: Perella Weinberg’s Xerion Said to Jump 24%
abstract: Perella Weinberg Partners‘ Xerion hedge fund rose 24 percent this year, Bloomberg News reported citing a letter sent to investors. The increase was helped by bets that the value of investment-grade bonds of financial-services firms would fall.

headline: NBC Fills Russert’s Bureau Chief Job
abstract: NBC named Mark Whitaker Monday as its next Washington bureau chief, succeeding the late Tim Russert. Mr. Whitaker, the former editor of Newsweek, has been a senior vice president of NBC News since 2007. The appointment has been widely expected because of Mr. Whitaker’s extensive journalism credentials.

headline: What a Lehman Bankruptcy Filing Might Look Like
abstract: Corrected: As many of Wall Street’s chieftains returned to 33 Liberty Street on Sunday morning, the situation surrounding a potential rescue plan for Lehman Brothers seemed as fluid as ever.

headline: CVS Stands By Longs Bid Despite Walgreen Offer
abstract: CVS Caremark says it is standing by its $2.7 billion bid for Longs Drug Stores, despite the announcement Friday by Walgreen Company that it had tabled a $3 billion offer for Longs.

headline: 2 Banks Buying Back $17 Billion in Securities
abstract: Two major Wall Street firms on Thursday offered to buy back more than $17 billion of troubled auction-rate securities that they had marketed as being as safe and liquid as cash, moving quickly to contain the legal fallout from the credit crisis.

headline: BP Makes Deep Concessions in Agreement With Russian Partner
abstract: In a deal that will allow BP to keep a crucial asset, but at a cost of ceding some control, the company came to an agreement with its Russian partners Thursday over its joint oil venture, ending months of acrimony and threats.

headline: How Some Companies Are Doing It Right
abstract: Two examples of tech companies that actually handle customer service well.

headline: Lone Star Seeks to Avoid Seoul Sanctions
abstract: Lone Star Funds has submitted documents requested by South Korean authorities that could help the private equity house avoid sanctions including the forced sale of its shares in Korea Exchange Bank, already offered to HSBC.

headline: As Banks Stumble, Hedge Funds Poach Talent
abstract: Hedge funds are on a hiring binge, taking advantage of cutbacks at investment banks. Star traders, senior executives and whole teams have been recruited by funds recently as they look to capitalize on the banks’ woes for their own expansion, The Financial Times reports.

headline: Will the Profit Motive Undermine Trust in Truste?
abstract: Truste, a non-profit trade association that certifies Web sites that meet basic privacy standards, is converting to a for-profit company and taking an investment from Accel Partners.

headline: Capula Investment Reaps Rewards for Goldman
abstract: Goldman Sachs, it seems, has made a good bet on one hedge fund firm, Capula Investment Management.

headline: Heikki’s wonderful victory
abstract: While it is true that Heikki Kovalainen owed his victory in large part to problems with both Lewis Hamilton’s and Felipe Massa’s car, I for one have been saying for several races now that Heikki is raising his game to a much higher level. I think this victory is a sign of that. Furthermore, I went so far as to predict to my Finnish colleague Heikki Kulta for his blog yesterday, that I thought Heikki would win the race. When he asked me why – I was the only journalist of those he asked to say this, apparently – I told him the same reasons mentioned above, but ultimately I said it was just a feeling I had about it.

headline: Leaving Baghdad: Comparing New York With Home
abstract: Ahmad Fadam left Baghdad bureau in May to take up a visiting fellowship at the University of North Carolina.

headline: In Olympic Ads, Obama Inspires While McCain Attacks
abstract: There is almost a template for commercials that appear during coverage of the Olympics. So it comes as something of a surprise that the commercial being run by the John McCain presidential campaign during the Summer Olympics is a negative one.

headline: Cardinal Health to Spin Off Products Unit
abstract: The drug wholesaler Cardinal Health said Monday it would spin off its high-margin clinical and medical products businesses as a stand-alone medical technology company.

headline: Sava Could Fetch Healthy $1 Billion
abstract: Sava Senior Care is up for sale and could fetch more than $1 billion, The Daily Deal reported citing investment banking sources.

headline: Thomas Cook Bails on Condor Merger Talks
abstract: Thomas Cook, Europe’s second-biggest tour operator, has withdrawn from discussions with TUI Travel and Lufthansa about a merger of its charter airline Condor with TUIfly and Germanwings.

headline: Aftra Approves New Union Contract
abstract: One Hollywood actors union approves a contract, giving another one a migraine.

headline: Dubai Developer’s Next Big Project: An I.P.O.?
abstract: In a year or so, it may not be necessary to move all the way to Dubai to own a piece of the emirate’s ostentatious man-made, palm-shaped islands.

headline: Shell Canada Pays $5.9 Billion for Gas Company
abstract: Duvernay Oil, a natural gas company based in Alberta, agreed on Monday to be acquired by a larger rival, Shell Canada, for $5.9 billion.

headline: Too Little Information, Then Too Much
abstract: An economist’s quite readable study identifies the cause of financial panic.

headline: Criticizing Capitalism From the Pulpit
abstract: Whatever happened to “God helps those who help themselves?”

headline: Tempted to Cash Out That 401(k)? Just Say No
abstract: Nina Smith, a personal finance blogger, weighs in on why people should resist the temptation to take money from a 401(k).

headline: Youku.com Lines Up $30 Million
abstract: Youku.com has secured $30 million in a financing round led by Maverick Capital, Variety reported. One of China’s leading online video sites, it will use the funding for expansion.

headline: ‘Secret Life’ More Popular Than ‘Gossip Girl’
abstract: “Secret Life of the American Teenager,” an upstart show on the ABC Family, is a clear hit for the cable channel.

headline: Microsoft Picks Greenfield for $486 Million
abstract: Microsoft on Friday announced its first major deal since failing to buy Yahoo , agreeing to acquire Web-based survey company Greenfield Online for about $486 million.

headline: Carl Icahn to Sit Out Yahoo Meeting
abstract: Carl Icahn has been a busy blogger. The latest posts on his Icahn Report, which appeared Thursday morning, comprise of a critique of the financial press and an explanation of why he dropped his proxy fight with Yahoo. He also said that, after months of highly public feuding with Yahoo, he won’t be making an appearance at its upcoming shareholder meeting.

headline: EDF Drops $23 Billion British Energy Bid
abstract: French power giant EDF  walked away from a 12 billion pound ($23.8 billion) deal to buy British Energy early on Friday in a dramatic U-turn that could delay Britain’s plans to relaunch its nuclear program.

headline: Yahoo’s Stock Hits 5-Year Low
abstract: Shares of Yahoo, which fended off an unwelcome takeover bid from Microsoft earlier this year, hit their lowest level in nearly five years on Thursday.

headline: There Are These People Who Try to Jump on Giant Mud-Covered Rubber Balls, See, And…
abstract: “Wipeout” has taken hits — and falls, tumbles, nosedives, plunges, and wipeouts — and turned them into a new hit for ABC. The network says it’s a sure bet to return next summer.

headline: Mittal Not Interested in Rio Tinto, For Now
abstract: Lakshmi Mittal did indeed consider buying a stake in bid target Rio Tinto to expand his interests in iron ore but has decided against it for now, sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.

headline: Wilmington Becomes First City to Convert to Digital Television
abstract: With the flick of an eight-foot switch at midday Monday, Wilmington, N.C. became the first market in the U.S. to make the change to digital-only broadcasting.

headline: Facebook Gets Friended by Malware
abstract: Facebook users have been targeted by spam and a rapidly mutating Internet worm, but the company says it is fighting off the attacks.

headline: Best Buy’s Break-Even iPhone Deal
abstract: Best Buy will soon start selling Apple’s iPhone, but one analyst said it may not make any profit on the phones themselves and will have to earn money from accessories.

headline: Australian Bank Ends Talks to Buy ABN Amro Units
abstract: Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the country’s biggest mortgage lender, said that it has pulled out of discussions to buy the Australian and New Zealand operations of ABN Amro from the Royal Bank of Scotland, blaming “uncertainty in world financial markets.”

headline: In London, Songs for the Recently Unemployed
abstract: Andrew Lloyd Webber hopes to rush to the rescue of all those London bankers who recently lost their jobs in the turbulent financial markets.

headline: Vivi Nevo, the Mysterious Media Powerhouse
abstract: Who is Vivi Nevo?

headline: Another EADS Executive Is Taken Into Custody
abstract: A judicial official says French police have detained a former Airbus president in an insider trading investigation at its parent company EADS.

headline: Vector’s Bids Rub Aladdin the Wrong Way
abstract: Aladdin Knowledge Systems, a maker of computer security products, has rejected two takeover proposals from private equity firm Vector Capital.

headline: Anheuser and InBev Enter Friendly Talks
abstract: In a reversal of its previous hostility to the idea, Anheuser-Busch is in active talks to sell itself to the Belgian brewer InBev in a friendly deal, people briefed on the matter said. InBev has raised its offer to $70 a share, more than the $65 it had originally offered, a person close to the talks said on Friday.

headline: Mr. Paulson’s Dangerous Proposal
abstract: Ben Stein has a big bone to pick with Henry M. Paulson Jr.

headline: UST’s Shares Catch Fire After Report of Deal Talks
abstract: Shares of UST, which makes the smokeless tobacco brands Skoal and Copenhagen, surged 24 percent after the opening bell on Friday. Investors were reacting to a report in The New York Times, which said the company was in talks to be acquired by Altria for more than $10 billion.

headline: AFDI!
abstract: What Sam Zell has wrought at the Tribune Company.

headline: A Compromise In The ‘Shut Up’ Standoff
abstract: Fox, Sony Pictures and the writers of the forthcoming animated comedy “Sit Down, Shut Up” have reached an agreement that will end a month-long contract standoff.

headline: Cerberus’ Aozora Bank Post 75% Drop in First Quarter Profit
abstract: Aozora Bank, the Japanese lender controlled by  Cerberus Capital Management, posted a 75 percent decline in said first-quarter profit, on the back of a drop in fees declined and shrinking returns on hedge fund investments.

headline: After the Truce, Yahoo Reports and Icahn Blogs
abstract: Carl C. Icahn wants you to know that, now that his proxy battle with Yahoo is over, he intends to blog more often. And he hinted that an upcoming post will be inspired by a recent article in The Wall Street Journal.

headline: A little night racing at the autodromo – or how a dry run turned wet
abstract: It was so dark during first practice in Monza this morning that it looked like a dry run for the Singapore Grand Prix in two weeks time, the first night race in Formula One. What certainly canceled out any such theory was that the darkness was caused by the heavens opening up and releasing so much rain on the track that all action at the session stopped with 16 minutes left as there was just too much rain.

headline: UnitedHealth Settles Backdating Lawsuit
abstract: UnitedHealth Group, the health insurer, said on Wednesday that it agreed to pay $895 million to settle a class-action lawsuit with the California Public Employees Retirement System, which is known as Calpers, and Alaska Plumbing and Pipefitting Industry Pension Trust.

headline: What’s Next for E.A. and Take-Two?
abstract: Take-Two Interactive’s nonchalance toward Electronic Arts’s decision to scrap its $2 billion hostile takeover bid for the video game maker may be part of a high-stakes tactic.

headline: Four Reasons Our Printers Are Getting Dusty
abstract: Consumer printer sales are flat. Are home printers just not as necessary any more?

headline: As Options Play Propels Schaeffler’s Success, Who’s Next?
abstract: Schaeffler, a family-owned automobile components maker, has won control of a larger rival, Continental, by using an unusual derivatives transaction that analysts said Thursday could leave other German companies vulnerable to similar raids, The International Herald Tribune reported.

headline: First Debate Draws 52.4 Million Viewers
abstract: The first presidential debate of the fall garnered an average of 52.4 million viewers on Friday.

headline: A.I.G. Posts a Large Loss as Housing Troubles Persist
abstract: American International Group, the big insurer, lost $5.3 billion in the second quarter as housing values slid and disruptions continued in the credit markets.

headline: McLaren appeal date set
abstract: FIA Statement

headline: Media Heavies Help Finance Trion World
abstract: Trion World Network, a developer of online games, has raised $70 million in Series C round of funding, according to The Hollywood Reporter.

headline: Cablevision Systems Mulls Spin-Off of Units
abstract: Could Cablevision spin off its programming unit?

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: Sweet-Tooth Economics
abstract: Some further thoughts on whether prepaid cards make their users less sensitive to prices.

headline: The Troop Debate: Dark Humor
abstract: Qassem H.J. is a newspaper cartoonist working in Iraq. He abbreviates his name to protect his identity. This is part of a week-long series of blog posts on the debate among ordinary Iraqis over the presence of American troops.

headline: United Artists to Keep Credit Line at Merrill, Report Says
abstract: Merrill Lynch‘s deal to be bought by Bank of America is not expected to affect the $500 million line of credit the bank extended to United Artists, the film studio run by Tom Cruise, The New York Post reported.

headline: Steve & Barry’s Said to Receive Bid from Hedge fund
abstract: Steve & Barry’s, the low-cost celebrity retailer which filed for bankruptcy protection last month, has received a takeover bid from a hedge fund in a bid keep the business from liquidation, The New York Post reported.

headline: How Much Will It Really Cost?
abstract: This weekend, Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson delivered his proposal for rescuing the financial system to Congress. In a three-page legislative bill, Mr. Paulson asked for as much as $700 billion in authority for Treasury to purchase mortgage-related assets. This three-page bill is sure to balloon to hundreds of pages as Congress grapples with the issue.

headline: TiVo Tying Up With Entertainment Weekly
abstract: TiVo is entering a deal with Entertainment Weekly that will allow its users to automatically record shows suggested by the magazine’s staff.

headline: The Troop Debate: Should We Stay or Should We Go?
abstract: This is the first in a week-long series of blog posts on the debate inside Iraq over the presence of American troops.

headline: Evercore Strikes $120 Million Deal With Mizuho
abstract: Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, has secured a $120 million investment from Japan’s Mizuho Corporate Bank by selling debt and warrants.

headline: Five Banks Said to Flip Through WaMu’s Books
abstract: Washington Mutual, the struggling savings and loan that is reportedly exploring options including a sale, has at least five potential suitors, according to press reports.

headline: Investors Wonder What’s Next for National City
abstract: Shares of National City dropped more than half on Monday as investors wondered which regional bank might need a merger partner as the sector suffered what analysts called a deepening crisis of confidence.

headline: Star-Ledger’s Owner Seeks Buyouts and Warns of a Sale
abstract: The Star-Ledger of Newark and a smaller sister paper need to eliminate at least 20 percent of their staff and win concessions from trade unions to stay afloat, their management said on Thursday, or the company will sell the papers and possibly close the smaller one.

headline: Lehman Buys Into Bike-Parts Maker
abstract: Lehman Brothers Merchant Banking said it would buy a 40 percent stake in Sram, a privately held maker of high-end bicycle parts based in Chicago. Financial terms of the deal weren’t disclosed.

headline: Refurb–What Is it?
abstract: What exactly is a refurbished product?

headline: Many Wealthy Investors Shift to Cash, HSBC Says
abstract: A substantial number of the world’s wealthiest people have moved their money out of stocks and bonds and into cash, the head of HSBC‘s Swiss private banking unit said on Monday.

headline: China’s Olympic-Size Deal Volume
abstract: For one symbol of China’s world-class ambitions, look no further than Friday’s lavish kickoff to the 2008 Beijing Olympics. For another symbol, consult its M&A statistics.

headline: Blackstone Said to Plan Wind-Farm Investment
abstract: Blackstone Group, the New York-based private equity firm, plans to invest more than 1 billion euros ($1.57 billion) in a project to build wind farms in the North Sea to generate electricity, people familiar with the matter told Reuters.

headline: More Firms Pull Asian I.P.O.’s as Markets Slide
abstract: Two more firms shelved plans for initial public offerings in Asia, adding further gloom to a market which recently showed signs of a revival after a dismal start to the year. The news comes on the heels of the shelving of Korea’s SK C&C‘s potential $1.2 billion I.P.O. due to averse market conditions.

headline: Macquarie Teams With Seek for Recruitment Site
abstract: Macquarie Group and Seek will invest a combined $105 million in Zhaopin, owner of China’s third-biggest recruitment Web site, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Reinventing Two Mortgage Giants: A Big Rebuild or a Teardown?
abstract: A day after the government seized control of the nation’s two largest mortgage finance companies, policy makers and Congress began what promises to be an epic political fight over how to revamp the companies once the current crisis ends, Stephen Labaton and Edmund L. Andrews wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Red Mango Scoops Up $12 Million
abstract: Red Mango, a longtime competitor of Pinkberry, said on Tuesday that it has raised $12 million in a series A round of financing, led by a former chief executive of Blockbuster and the Dallas-based private equity firm CIC Partners.

headline: The Emmys: In the Category of ‘Cheapest Reality Show That Pays the Network’s Bills,’ the Nominees Are…
abstract: A reality competition will play out in real time during the 60th Primetime Emmy Awards on Sunday: the five hosts of the broadcast will be competing in the new category of “outstanding host of a reality or reality-competition show.”

headline: Apple’s Capricious Rules for iPhone Apps
abstract: Apple told a developer that it won’t distribute his podcasting application through the iPhone Apps Store because it competes with Apple’s iTunes software.

headline: Judge Delays Hedge Fund Manager’s Hearing
abstract: A hedge-fund manager accused of faking his own suicide tried to plead guilty to bail jumping on Wednesday, but his case was postponed after he told the judge that his drug therapy was affecting his ability to think clearly.

headline: A Risk Manager’s Post Mortem
abstract: An anonymous risk manager gave a first-person account of the recently-deflated credit boom to The Economist, recounting the time when his or her profession was considered obsolete.

headline: Winners and Losers
abstract: As the stock market goes back to gyrating –the Dow has been up more than 100 points, and down more than 200, during the first two hours — here, courtesy of Howard Silverblatt of Standard & Poor’s, are the Lucky 13 and the Unlucky 13 for this year.

headline: The Road to Anbar
abstract: BAGHDAD — This spring I needed to interview former detainees in American detention centers who had recently been released, so I went to Anbar Province, a vast western desert area of Iraq that lies between Baghdad and Jordan. It is best known for the turbulent town of Falluja, which became a headquarters for Al Qaeda in Iraq and where the Americans fought bloody battles in 2004. It then became something of a ghost town peopled almost exclusively by fighters. Eventually, the Marines completely controlled it and the violence migrated elsewhere. But many of those who had been detained there were locals, and eventually they returned to their homes.

headline: BioImagene Raises $26 Million in Fourth Round
abstract: Medical imaging company BioImagene has raised $26 million in a fourth round of venture funding, led by Burrill & Company.

headline: Lehman Cuts May Presage More Bloodletting
abstract: Word of 1,500 job cuts at Lehman Brothers shows that on Wall Street, the ax keeps falling again and again. And as the financial industry limps from one bleak quarter to the next, bankers and traders who dodged painful layoffs in the past year wonder if their luck is running out.

headline: BofA’s Merrill Deal Brings Risks and Opportunity
abstract: Last Friday, Kenneth D. Lewis, chief executive of the Bank of America Corporation, was in his headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., pondering a possible acquisition of Lehman Brothers, the foundering investment bank.

headline: Emmy Nominations: A Second Strong Year For ’30 Rock’
abstract: “30 Rock” was the most recognized series overall with 17 nominations.

headline: Analyzing Wall Street’s Research
abstract: At a recent conference, Frank P. Quattrone, the former star analyst, opined that former New York attorney general Eliot Spitzer’s landmark research analysts settlement had been disastrous for the quality of research. DealBook’s Andrew Ross Sorkin agrees that there’s a problem — but finds a solution more elusive.

headline: New York to Regulate Credit-Default Swaps
abstract: Gov. David A. Paterson said Monday that New York would begin regulating credit-default swaps, the arcane financial instruments that were little known outside Wall Street before the credit crisis, The New York Times’s Danny Hakim reported.

headline: Microsoft Tries to Polish Vista
abstract: Microsoft is said to be starting an expensive campaign to reassure consumers that its Vista operating system isn’t all that bad.

headline: Mitsubishi Sees $506 Million Paper Loss on Morgan Stake
abstract: Among the casualties of the House of Representatives’ rejection of the proposed $700 billion rescue package: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group‘s $9 billion investment in Morgan Stanley.

headline: Moody’s Profit Falls 48%
abstract: The Moody’s Corporation, the parent of Moody’s Investors Service, said on Wednesday quarterly profit fell 48 percent, as the year-long credit crisis caused demand to shrink for mortgage bonds and the mortgage bundles known as collateralized debt obligations.

headline: Australian Funds Decry Shorting Clampdown in U.S.
abstract: Australian hedge fund players have come out swinging against the United States’ efforts to curb short selling, arguing that hedge funds are being targeted as the scapegoat for falling markets.

headline: Biden’s Son Caught Up in Hedge Fund Troubles
abstract: A son and a brother of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the newly named Democratic vice-presidential candidate, are accused in two lawsuits of defrauding a former business partner and an investor of millions of dollars in a hedge fund deal that went sour.

headline: Waiting for the Zune Generation
abstract: Microsoft continues to press its Zune line, despite being trounced in the market by Apple. Babies are born every day that don’t yet have iPods, the company says hopefully.

headline: K.K.R. Hires Ex-Edison Chief as Senior Adviser
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Monday that it has hired John E. Bryson, the former chairman and chief executive of Edison International, a California power company, as a senior adviser for its new infrastructure efforts.

headline: Heigl To Continue On ‘Grey’s Anatomy’
abstract: Katherine Heigl will remain on “Grey’s Anatomy” next season, despite speculation that she wanted to free herself from her commitment to the series, Stephen McPherson, the president of ABC Entertainment, said Wednesday.

headline: Imperial in Talks With Indian Rival Over $2.8 Billion Deal
abstract: British oil and gas explorer Imperial Energy said Tuesday that it is in talks to sell itself for 1.4 billion pounds ($2.8 billion) to India’s ONGC Videsh, in a deal The Financial Times said is expected to be approved by Imperial later Tuesday.

headline: Another in an occasional series of F1 travel stories
abstract: A year ago I wrote about my travel woes in Istanbul while going to the race from downtown. I figured it was a good travel tip sort of way of getting off some of my own steam and heat. I suppose I’m in for one of these once a year – and if that’s all it takes, then so be it.

headline: Which Way Is Up? Yahoo, Microsoft and Icahn Can’t Agree
abstract: Microsoft, Yahoo and Carl C. Icahn can’t even agree on the basic facts about what happened last weekend. No wonder they can’t engineer some kind of deal.

headline: AOL Talks with Microsoft or Yahoo Said to Pick Up
abstract: Time Warner‘s discussions to merge or sell its AOL Internet division with Microsoft or Yahoo have taken on new urgency ahead of Yahoo’s Aug. 1 shareholders meeting, a source familiar with the discussions told Reuters on Tuesday.

headline: Fresenius to Buy APP Pharmaceuticals
abstract: Fresenius, the giant German maker of dialysis services and products, said Monday that it will buy APP Pharmaceuticals for for about $4.6 billion including debt, giving it control of one of the biggest makers of generic injectable drugs.

headline: Pressure Builds as Lehman Faces Mounting Losses
abstract: The trouble at Lehman Brothers is rapidly becoming a race against time for the struggling Wall Street bank, The New York Times’ Ben White writes.

headline: The Best Business Books Ever?
abstract: Regular readers of my column–and I mean really regular readers — might recall that several years ago, I asked for nominations of good examples of business fiction written in the last 25 years. I promised to return to the subject in a future column once readers weighed in. This was a promise, alas, I failed to keep. Once I got the nominations, I bought many of the books, but there they sat, on the floor of my office, looking at me balefully for months, begging to be read. I just couldn’t do it. Doug Coupland’s brand of alienated-office-drone fiction didn’t move me.

headline: Inside Sadr City: Friday Prayers
abstract: Video

headline: Ex-Siemens Manager Convicted of Corruption
abstract: A German court on Monday convicted a former manager at Siemens of misuse of funds, in the first – but probably not the last – verdict stemming from a bribery scandal at the giant engineering and electronics company.

headline: Pickens Calls Yahoo Management ‘Pathetic’
abstract: It looks like Yahoo has ticked off another billionaire.

headline: Roche Offers $43.7 Billion for Rest of Genetech
abstract: The Swiss drug maker Roche Holding said Monday that it was offering about $43.7 billion to acquire the 44 percent of the biotechnology company Genentech that it does not already own.

headline: Merger of Sirius and XM Approved by F.C.C.
abstract: Federal regulators have formally approved the merger of the nation’s only two satellite radio operators in a deal closely watched by Washington and Wall Street.

headline: Genentech Weighs Roche’s Takeover Bid
abstract: Genentech said Thursday that the company had formed a special committee, consisting of its three independent board members, to consider a takeover bid from Roche Holding.

headline: For HSBC, the New iPhone May Prove Alluring
abstract: HSBC is considering replacing the BlackBerry with Apple’s new iPhone 3G as the mobile device of its global workforce, the banking giant’s Australia and New Zealand chief information officer told ZDNet Australia.

headline: Apple Sues Psystar to Block Macintosh Clone Sales
abstract: Apple has sued Psystar, a Florida-based maker of Macintosh clones, claiming that the company makes poor-quality machines that infringe on Apple’s trademarks. Apple wants the company to stop making the clones and recall the ones already sold.

headline: Reading a Tea Leaf in the Take-Two Saga
abstract: From Bits: Electronic Arts has hired Joele Frank, a specialist in public relations for mergers and acquisitions. But it’s unclear what her hiring means for the prospects of a deal between EA and Take-Two Interactive.

headline: ‘SNL’ Returns to Spotlight
abstract: The premiere of “SNL” is Saturday — Michael Phelps is hosting — and it’s one of the most anticipated seasons in the 34-year history of the comedy institution.

headline: AT&T Pushes for Review of Competitors’ WiMax Venture
abstract: AT&T has begun lobbying the the Federal Communications Commission to mount a review of a proposed deal between its competitors Sprint Nextel and Clearwire to create the first of a new generation of nationwide wireless data networks.

headline: Olympics: Timing Was Everything
abstract: Why did the Olympics begin on August 8?

headline: Pakistan Considers Asset Sales to Bolster Economy
abstract: Pakistan plans to sell valuable energy assets, beginning with a major gas field, as it tries to reap billions of dollars from deals with investors in industries like banking and farming, The New York Times’ Heather Timmons reported.

headline: Alitalia Gets Its Rescue Deal
abstract: Alitalia‘s prospective owners, with key unions finally backing their rescue plan, say they are shifting their focus to forming a tie-up with either Air France-KLM or Lufthansa and launching the new airline by November 1.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Sell 21 Percent Stake
abstract: A week after announcing it would sell as much as 20 percent of itself to Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Morgan Stanley revealed the terms of the investment Monday morning.

headline: Call Him Deputy Attorney General Pitt
abstract: As chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey Pitt used to fume as state attorneys general started investigations of areas that he thought were the proper province of his agency.

headline: Buyers Found for Troubled British Lender’s Rights Offering
abstract: Bradford & Bingley shareholders and the biggest British banks are planning to buy most of the 400 million pounds ($789 million) of stock that Bradford & Bingley will sell to prevent a second failure in the country’s financial industry.

headline: Short-Sale Conspiracies
abstract: Deutsche Bank has been hit with a $575,000 fine, and a censure, over its failure to abide by short-sale rules a couple of years ago.

headline: Intel Bets on the Past
abstract: One of Intel’s chief advantages is that Microsoft’s MS-DOS operating system will be booting on the teraflop Intel microprocessor in every personal computer of the future. Intel beleives that because it has always believed in backward compatibility. In the world of handhelds and smartphones, that may not be enough of a margin.

headline: Citadel Takes Stake in RadioShack
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the Chicago-based firm run by Kenneth Griffin, has tuned into RadioShack, buying 6.9 million shares, or 5.3 percent of the electronics retail chain’s stock, according to a filing Monday.

headline: Harbinger Executive Said to Leave Firm
abstract: Howard Kagan, one of three managing directors at Harbinger Capital and a director of investments, is no longer at the $21 billion hedge fund — and may have been pushed out, according to The New York Post.

headline: Tough Road Ahead for China’s State Banks
abstract: China’s huge state banks are poised to report strong profit growth for the first half in 2008, thanks to wider margins and strong fee income, but funding costs are expected to rise in the second half, eroding growth, analysts say.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Leads Round for Zynga
abstract: Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has led a considerable $29 million round for Zynga Game Network, which makes casual games for social-networking Web sites like Facebook.

headline: It’s O.K. to Be Middle-Aged on TV Land
abstract: TV Land, the Viacom cable channel known for nostalgia, wants to seem new.

headline: In Turnabout, Russia to Allow Permits for BP Workers
abstract: In a sign of apparent backpedaling by officials here, the Russian government said on Wednesday that it would expedite work permits for the chief executive of a BP joint venture, and five other senior staff members.

headline: Welcoming Another Contributor
abstract: Introducing Uwe E. Reinhardt, who will write regularly for Economix.

headline: Labor Union Said to Call for Stricter Rules for Private Equity
abstract: The Service Employees International Union is apparently none too pleased with reported efforts by private equity firms to persuade the Federal reserve and other agencies to loosen ownership rules of banks.

headline: Hedge Funds Sprout in Gaps in Real-Estate Lending
abstract: With money still tight, investors in real estate are forced to turn to hard-money lenders, who charge high interest for short-term loans. More often than not these days, those lenders are hedge funds, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Yahoo’s Anticlimactic Shareholder Meeting
abstract: With Carl Icahn’s proxy fight for control of Yahoo’s board ending in a settlement, Yahoo’s shareholder meeting Friday is an anticlimax.

headline: Cisco Buys E-Mail and Calendaring Start-Up for $215 Million
abstract: Cisco announced Wednesday it will acquire PostPath, a venture-backed start-up that provides open-source email and calendaring software, for $215 million.

headline: Alabama County Prepares for a Possible Bankruptcy Filing
abstract: Officials of Jefferson County in Alabama told their lawyers to prepare a bankruptcy filing if the county was unable to reach an agreement with creditors over how to escape from $3 billion of bonds with soaring interest rates.

headline: Union of Whole Foods and Wild Oats Is Put in Doubt
abstract: The marriage between Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats Markets was thrown into doubt again on Tuesday, at least temporarily, by a federal appeals court, which ruled that a lower court judge had inadequately considered the impact on customers.

headline: Former Morgan Stanley Executive Charged with Insider Trading
abstract: A former Morgan Stanley banker has been arrested and charged with insider trading in Hong Kong, the local securities watchdog said.

headline: Ads We Love
abstract: Even among TiVo users who can fast-forward through the advertisements, the Coca-Cola commercial just before the announcement of the “American Idol” winner was the most-watched ad in the month of May, according to a report by the digital video recorder manufacturer.

headline: Loopt Eagerly Joins the iPhone Gold Rush
abstract: Loopt, a mobile social-networking service, was eager to develop an application for the iPhone, despite the restrictions Apple placed on its partners.

headline: RAB Capital Co-Founder Steps Down as Chief
abstract: RAB Capital is removing its co-founder, Philip Richards, from his role as chief executive, as the British hedge fund faces shrinking profits after a series of wrong bets, including an investment in the troubled British lender Northern Rock, which was ultimately nationalized.

headline: Icahn’s Problems With Proxy Contests
abstract: Carl C. Icahn seems to be getting the hang of blogging. The activist investor has a new post up on his site, The Icahn Report, for the second time this week, and this time he gripes about proxy contests.

headline: Few Buyers for TV Guide Network
abstract: TV Guide Network is formally up for sale now, months after its new owner, Macrovision, indicated that it would put the network on the market.

headline: Pickens’ Loses $1 Billion on Energy Bets, Report Says
abstract: T. Boone Pickens, it seems, has taken a bath on his energy investments.

headline: Morgan Stanley Asian P.E. Arm Shoots for Ten Arrows
abstract: Morgan Stanley‘s Asian private equity arm is set to launch a tender offer to take control of Japan’s Ten Arrows via a $105 million management buyout, according to Finance Asia.

headline: Banks’ Return on Equity in Decline
abstract: A slump in the lucrative structured-finance business and regulators’ demands for bigger capital reserves mean that stratospheric profitability at banks is gone, possibly forever.

headline: Best Buy Bails Out Failing Napster
abstract: From Saul Hansell at Bits:

headline: Does Silicon Valley Face an Innovation Crisis?
abstract: Judy Estrin, a serial technology entrepreneur, says in a new book that Silicon Valley — and the country — are facing a crisis of innovation.

headline: Yahoo’s Advisory Bill Hits $36 Million
abstract: Jerry Yang and his fellow Yahoos have spent plenty of time and energy in recent months dealing with Microsoft’s unsolicited takeover offer and the proxy fight it inspired. Now, Yahoo has shed some light on how much this upheaval has cost in actual dollars and cents — specifically, it revealed the fees it has racked up for outside advice from bankers and lawyers.

headline: National Foods Offers $784 Million for Australia’s Dairy Farmers
abstract: National Foods, which is owned by Japan’s Kirin, has agreed to buy the Australian dairy producer Dairy Farmers for 910 million Australian dollars, or $784 million, the companies said on Monday.

headline: Google Now Allows You to Pick Your Friends in Reader
abstract: Responding to Web critics, Google has modified its Reader service to allow users to choose the people who have access to their list of favorite blog items.

headline: E.U. Approves Hewlett-Packard’s $13.9 Billion Deal for E.D.S.
abstract: Hewlett-Packard said Friday that the European Commission has approved its planned acquisition of Electronic Data Systems without conditions.

headline: Vodafone Announces $2 Billion Stock Buyback
abstract: Vodafone Group, the world’s biggest mobile phone operator, announced a surprise stock buyback valued at about $2 billion Wednesday, saying a big share price fall Tuesday had left it undervalued.

headline: Sun Valley: A Party for the Mogul-Movers
abstract: As dusk settled on the Pioneer Mountains in Sun Valley, Idaho, last Thursday, the party was just beginning: a group of close to 100 people with name tags, mostly men, mingled, drank beer and told stories of their day on the golf course or at other diversions, like fly fishing or skeet shooting.

headline: A perfect lap, but no overtaking
abstract: Felipe Massa took the pole position with what he called “a pefect lap.” And he did this on a track where Lewis Hamilton, who set the second fastest time, said definitively this evening, “We won

headline: Ford Plans $500 Million Share Sale
abstract: Ford Motor said Friday it will sell $500 million in common stock to pay off debt at its financing arm, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: Emmy Nominations: Voters Embrace Dark, Tormented TV Characters
abstract: “It would be hard to imagine a darker, more motley collection of misfits than the characters played with convincing aplomb by the six Emmy nominees for best lead actor in a drama series.”

headline: A Second-Generation Fink Rises in Finance
abstract: Joshua Fink, the 30-year-old son of BlackRock cofounder Laurence Fink, is taking up the family profession by heading up a $700 million hedge fund, according to The New York Post.
